headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, and welcome to the First Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Mr. Jeff Dodge. Please go ahead, sir.
componenttext:
Good day, and welcome to the First Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded. 
At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Mr. Jeff Dodge. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, and good morning. Welcome to today's conference call. I'm Jeff Dodge, Investor Relations, and with me today are Rick Smith, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and John Gamble, Chief Financial Officer. Today's call is being recorded. An archive
componenttext:
Thanks, and good morning. Welcome to today's conference call. I'm Jeff Dodge, Investor Relations, and with me today are Rick Smith, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and John Gamble, Chief Financial Officer. Today's call is being recorded. An archive of the recording will be available later today in the Investor Relations section of the About Equifax tab of our website at www.equifax.com. 
During this call, we'll be making certain forward-looking statements to help you understand Equifax and its business environment. These statements involve a number of risks, uncertainties and other factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from our expectations. Certain risk factors inherent in our business are set forth in filings with the SEC, including our 2014 Form 10-K and subsequent filings. We will be referring to certain non-GAAP financial measures, including adjusted EPS attributable to Equifax and adjusted operating margin that will be adjusted for certain items, which affect the comparability of the underlying operational performance. Adjusted EPS attributable to Equifax excludes acquisition-related amortization expense and the associated tax effects and the charge principally related to the realignment of internal resources to more effectively support the company's strategic objectives. Adjusted operating margin excludes the onetime charge principally related to the realignment of our internal resources. These measures are detailed in our non-GAAP reconciliation tables included in our earnings release and also posted on our website. Also, please refer to our various investor presentations, which are posted in the Investor Relation section of our website, www.equifax.com for further details. 
Now I'd like to turn it over to Rick.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jeff, and good morning, everyone. As always, thank you for making time for join us this morning. The first quarter's performance was very robust and significantly exceeded our expectations. As you'll hear throughout my comments and John's comments
componenttext:
Thanks, Jeff, and good morning, everyone. As always, thank you for making time for join us this morning. The first quarter's performance was very robust and significantly exceeded our expectations. As you'll hear throughout my comments and John's comments in the question-and-answer period will be at the growth for the quarter was very broad-based. It was across all business units, across many verticals and across many countries. USIS and Workforce Solutions, in particular, posted an exceptional quarter. USIS out-strengthened the Decision 360 initiative, enterprise selling strategy, direct-to-consumer channel partners, mortgage and home equity lending. Workforce Solutions saw broad strength in Verification Services, including government, automotive and mortgage as well as solid strength in its employee services business. The revenue strength in both of those business nice margin expansions as you saw. Also, International and PSol finished very solid performances for the quarter. 
In total, the revenue was $652 million, up 12% on a reported basis, up 14.4% on a local currency basis versus the first quarter of 2014. In the quarter, FX created $17 million of year-over-year headwind, an increase from the fourth quarter of last year, which is $13 million of headwind. The adjusted operating margin was 27.2%, up 120 basis points from the first quarter of 2014. Adjusted EPS was $1.07, up 20% from $0.89 a share last year and significantly above the upper end of the guidance we provided a few months ago. We'll [indiscernible] by business year highlights, and then John will get into the details of the financials. I'll start as I always do with USCIS. There, the Decision 360 initiative, New Product Innovation and enterprise selling team delivered 14% revenue growth and healthy 42.4% operating margin, up 520 basis points from last year. 
Couple of highlights. Our relationship with Credit Karma, when we talked about in the past, they went live in January and generated transaction volumes exceeding our original projections. In addition to purchasing our credit information, Credit Karma is also using our freemium thought and identity authentication solutions provide consumers with online access to the credit information. Originally, we're part of a [indiscernible] solution with Credit Karma, and we believe this will ultimately lead to a [indiscernible] solution in an effort to better maximize to the consumers. 
As I mentioned in the last call, in recent quarters, one of the things we're seeing is that the financial institutions are changing the way they originate their consumer accounts and Financial Marketing Services, FMS. The traditional prescreen activity are giving away to more targeted one-on-one online offers. We talked about again this last few quarter. And as a result, our revenue mix is shifting towards higher margin online solutions. Growth in prescreen revenues has moderated somewhat. 
Net-net, I think at shifted the benefit to USIS. As you know, the full commercial USIS few quarters ago. Our commercial business is off to a great start recording the best first quarter performance since 2007, with record revenue and operating margin performance. Mortgage originations in home equity lending were also stronger in the quarter as low interest rate environment and lending activity has exceeded our expectations for the quarter. We'll get into that in the Q&A and compare the MD&A. Our core tribunal reporting volume was up 18% and will also experience strong growth in our high-value Undisclosed Debt Monitoring product services as lenders continue with our more rigorous underwriting standards. The pace of mortgage refinancing activity in home equity lending continues to be solid, and we expect it will moderate as we talked about back in February. Some we're going to expect in second [ph] quarter and continue to moderate as we exit the year. USIS growth rate is expected to be strong over the course of the year and be comfortably above its long-term growth range of 5% to 7% for the full year. 
On the International, they posted double-digit local currency growth in 5 countries, including the U.K. We continued to make good progress with the integration of TDX, which delivered constant currency revenue growth in excess of 25% for the first quarter. And also, leveraging NPI further, their market position as many of their products revenue about their expectation for the quarter around the world. 
International's ongoing effort to diversify its revenue base is underscored by double-digit constant currency growth from their SME customer base, retail customers, insurance customers, government customers and utility customers around the globe. 
Also, all verticals, including financial, our decision and analytics solutions are strengthening relationships with our customers and opening new opportunities to NPI and new sources of growth going forward. 
International's operating margin performance is also improving. Excluding TDX and all the investments we're making in TDX, International's operating margin expanded by approximately 190 basis points in the quarter when compared to the first quarter of 2014. During the quarter, we executed the debt recovery services contract with here Majesty's government in U.K. we talked about last time. That's resulting in continued investment in TDX as we prepare to ramp up and go live sometime in late third quarter for this multiyear U.K. government opportunity. So net-net, that opportunity is on pace and on track on almost every dimension. And again, we expect some modest revenue at the back end of this year ramping up in 2014. 
In addition, the unique capabilities of TDX and also in Phoenix, that's what we bought in Mexico, those capabilities are being leverage another geographic markets where we do not simply have credit information operating units. This year, International will be launching its Latin American regionalization strategy. That what Jeff kind of alluded to. That includes people, process and system changes. This effort will further streamline our operations and provide incremental operating leverage for International. It will also improve customer service and accelerate our time for revenue for new product innovation. 
For the year, we expect revenue growth to be solidly in the long-term range of 7% to 10% growth in International with improved operating margins as we exit the year. 
On to EWS. Their momentum accelerated in the quarter, remarkable performance. This broad-based revenue growth of 24%, up from 15% growth in the fourth quarter, and margins were up an astonishing 800 basis points from first quarter of last year to 40.3% for the quarter. Verification Services continue to make great progress penetrating our targeted non-mortgage markets. We delivered strong double-digit growth in home equity lending, auto, card, consumer finance, government and preemployment. And finally, growth in the mortgage activity drove a very healthy 34% growth in overall Verification Services revenue. In addition, our penetration of pure lending space with our employment and income Verification Services have delivered strong new sources of growth. 
We now have over 4,500 companies contributing their employment and income information into The Work Number database, and this number of companies are growing on a monthly basis. The outlook for 2015 continues to be very good. Although mortgage originations are expected to slow, our revenues in various ACA initiatives further penetration of employment income verification in non-mortgage markets. And our strategic initiatives in employee services are expected to offset the mortgage decreased later this year, resulting in full year revenue growth, well-above the top end of the multiyear range and margin expansion in the range of the neighborhood of 350 basis points or more versus 2014. 
On to PSol. Constant currency revenue growth was at the upper end of the multiyear range, and operating margins continue to be strong. In addition, we're making good progress on the strategic transformation. Double-digit growth in indirect Canada and U.K. were the major contributors to growth in the quarter. For our direct-to-consumer activity, the U.S. key operating metric, average revenue per subscriber insurance continue to improve. 
2015 will be a good transformational year for PSol as we talked about in the past. They are making good progress on [indiscernible] strengthening the core U.S.-based business and developing strong marketing position in the indirect space; and three, growing our International presence in Canada and the U.K. We expect Personal Solutions to end the year with revenue comfortably within our multiyear target range. 
Let me go back to corporate and give you some highlights of a corporate level, and then I'll turn it over to John for the financials. I think we spent about 9 years not talk about how NPI drives growth and talk about 3 points of growth coming from NPI and we deliver those 3 points of growth for us in the first quarter. There's another very important  growth driver, which we launched about 3 or 4 years. We don't talk a lot about, and we launched it across all our business units and that's what we call Enterprise Growth Initiatives, EDI for us. It's a very systematically for managing multimillion-dollar revenue initiatives and overwhelmed with resources and process and senior management attention gives importance to our long-term growth. Our EGI initiatives had a banner first quarter performance with strong double-digit growth, exceeding our expectations for the quarter. And our outlook for the year continues to be for very strong year-on-year growth coming from EGI. 
Also, at the corporate level, we're talking how we develop a strong reputation of customers regarding our expertise in marine, and we're doing this globally. We're not only leveraging this relationship through our existing customers but continue to drive incremental revenue growth but will also open doors with noncustomers around the world because we have patiently developed some of our very key verticals. It gives us yet another opportunity to grow revenue for strong customer partnerships and really differentiate our offerings to these customers in yet another dimension. Our global fraud initiatives, which crossed our all of our B2B business units, delivered double-digit growth in the quarter as well. 
In summary, the quarter's performance is the strongest first quarter performance we've experienced in many years. Sequential revenue growth from the fourth quarter was up 4.4%, whereas in the past years, we typically experience modest or even declining sequential growth. Adjusted operating margin expanded 70 basis points in the fourth quarter, and adjusted earnings per share increased almost 5% from the fourth quarter when we usually see declining sequential growth. Despite this unprecedented performance, we're still early in the year and there's still some uncertainties out there in macroeconomic challenges around the globe. However, we are more optimistic now than we were when we entered the year. 
I'll turn it over to you, John, for some financials, and I'll come back with some closing comments.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rick, and good morning, everyone. As before, I'll be referring to the financial results from continuing operations generally presented on a GAAP basis. Now during the quarter, we recorded a charge of $23.4 million, principally related to the rea
componenttext:
Thanks, Rick, and good morning, everyone. As before, I'll be referring to the financial results from continuing operations generally presented on a GAAP basis. 
Now during the quarter, we recorded a charge of $23.4 million, principally related to the realignment of internal resources to more effectively support our strategic objectives. The was primarily driven by the regionalization, consolidation strategy in International, including the integration of TDX; consolidation of functions related to the integration of commercial into USIS; and then some realignment actions across the remainder of the business. The cost were 2/3 severance but also include related real estate, legal and other costs. The costs are reflected in SG&A and the general corporate expense line of our financial statements. The actions will occur throughout 2015 and should be completed within 12 months. Ongoing savings, once the actions are complete, are expected to be $10 million to $15 million per year, with limited incremental benefit in 2015. 
Now consistent with our past practice, we're treating unusual or infrequent items. We've excluded this charge from our adjusted EPS and adjusted operating margin in order to provide investors with a more consistent period-to-period operating comparison. The FX impact on revenue and EPS this quarter were consistent with our expectations that we provided to you in February. 
Now let me turn to the business units financial performance for the quarter. U.S. Information Solutions revenue was $299 million, up 14% when compared to the first quarter. Online Information Solutions revenue was $222 million, up 15% when compared to the year-ago period. Mortgage Solutions revenue was $31 million, up 28% compared to Q1 2014. These trends compare favorably to the Mortgage Bankers Application Index, which was up 21% in the first quarter. Financial Marketing Services revenue was $46 million, up 3% when compared to the year-ago quarter. As Rick mentioned earlier, the slower growth reflects a shift in how financial institutions originating their accounts to 1:1 online solicitations. The operating margin for U.S. Information Solutions was 42.4%, up from 37.2% in the first quarter of 2013. We continue to expect USIS to have operating margins in the low 40s, consistent with our long-term model in 2015. 
International's revenue was $139 million, down 1% on a reported basis, but up 10% on a local currency basis. By region, Europe's revenue was $58 million, up 1% in U.S. dollars and up 12% on local currency. Latin America's revenue was $48 million, up 2% in U.S. dollars and 13% in local currency. Canada revenue was $33 million, down 9% in U.S. dollars, but up 3% in local currency. For the first quarter, International operating margin was 20.2%, down slightly from 20.6% in the first quarter 2014. This reduction in margin was principally due to FX. For the full year, we continue to expect the operating margin to expand slightly compared to 2014. 
Workforce Solutions revenue was $149 million for the quarter, up 24% when compared to the first quarter of 2014. Verification Services with revenue of $86 million was up 34% when compared to the same quarter in 2014. Employer Services revenue was $63 million, up 13% compared to last year. Following the Lockheed hiatus in 2014, processing their backlog during the first quarter. Also, revenue from our ACA analytical solutions was very strong in the quarter. The Workforce Solutions operating margin was 40.3% compared to 32.3% in Q1 of 2014. The marketing benefited from the Lockheed renewal, which contributed approximately 3 percentage points to the margin in the quarter. For the full year 2015, we continue to expect Workforce Solutions operating margin to be in the range of 36% to 37%. 
Personal Solutions revenue was $66 million, up 4% and a reported basis and up 6% on a local currency basis. For the first quarter, operating margin was 27.4% compared to 28.5% in Q1 2014. This year-over-year reduction is consistent with our expectations and the guidance we gave for Q1 and the full year. 
In the first quarter, general corporate expense, at $78.4 million, was up significantly, reflecting the $23.4 million realignment charge I mentioned previously. Excluding this charge, general corporate expense was $55 million, up $8.7 million sequentially and $24.3 million versus 1Q '15 -- versus 1Q '14. This increase is principally due to increased incentive and equity compensation and benefit expense. This reflects the very strong performance in 1Q '15 as well as earlier timing of annual equities expense in 2015 versus 2014. We also saw increased professional legal and regulatory costs in 1Q '15 versus 1Q '14. 
Looking at 2Q '15, we expect general corporate expense to be down $10 million sequentially on an adjusted basis, reflecting lower equity expense and at or slightly below the Q2 level in both Q3 and Q4. Operating cash flow was $103 million in the first quarter. Cash flow grew faster than earnings, reflecting positive working capital performance. We continue our aggressive stock buyback activity, repurchasing 1 million shares for $90 million and paid $35 million in dividends to our shareholders. Our leverage remains a very conservative 1.75x EBITDA. 
Now let me turn it back to Rick.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. Thanks, John. Quick outlook for guidance the second quarter and the total year. I'll give you some numbers just to put in perspective with the influence of the mortgage market as it relates to second quarter and the balance of the year. Again, we e
componenttext:
Great. Thanks, John. Quick outlook for guidance the second quarter and the total year. I'll give you some numbers just to put in perspective with the influence of the mortgage market as it relates to second quarter and the balance of the year. Again, we expect the market to -- the mortgage market performance, like we talked about back in February, a bit second quarter and then continue to moderate even further year-on-year in the third and fourth quarter. 
So for the second quarter, we expect organic revenue to be between $655 million and $665 million. That is in constant currency organic, revenue growth rate of 10% to 12%, and that's partially offset by the 3 points of FX headwind. Adjusted EPS is expected to be between $1.09 and $1.11, which is up 14% to 16%, excluding $0.02 per share of negative impact from FX. This reflects constant currency growth rate of 16% to 18% for the quarter. We also expect operating margin to continue to improve in the quarter in the range of 27.5% to 28%. 
Obviously, there's some uncertainty for the balance of the year, its macroeconomic uncertainty around the world and U.S. economic uncertainty, some uncertainty in the Middle East, uncertainty in Latin America. So against that uncertain backdrop, I'm convinced that this team will continue to execute extremely well and continue to drive above-market growth across all our other businesses and all our verticals in the second quarter and the balance of the year. So with that and based upon the current level of domestic and International business activity and the FX rates, we expect 2015 to have a revenue range of $2.585 billion to $2.635 billion, which is up from our previous guidance. This reflects constant currency organic revenue growth of 8% to 11% for the year. The strong revenue growth is partially offset by 3 points of negative impact from FX. And again, as reported, this is only organic revenue growth at this time. 
2015 adjusted EPS, we expect to be in the range of $4.28 and $4.35 per share, also above from our previous guidance. This reflects 10%, 12% growth in 2015. FX impact for the year, as we previously stated in the last earnings call, is expected to be about $0.11 for the year and we have -- 11% [ph] for the year -- $0.11 [ph] per the year. We have $0.02 share impact in the first quarter, which says we have a remaining $0.09 per share impact for the full year. 
So with that, operator, let's open for any questions you might have.

componenttext: No, it's specific to the second quarter, and I'll come back to the balance of the year. There are 2 primary drivers when we look at sequential growth and you get one towards which is the mortgage market. And the other is, I think alluded to it in my comments, the -- contract, tax credit contract, which we monetized in the first quarter this year, a bit last year as well. Doesn't repeat. It's really it's a 1 quarter, largely 1 quarter activity. So that's the new one, if you will, for the second quarter. And now for the balance of the year, the third and fourth quarter, which is till very solid, I think you'd agree. It's really answer to you on a macro basis. Interest rate environment, regulatory environment around the world, economic environment, so on and so forth, geopolitical issues and this uncertainty there. That's about it.

componenttext: Yes. I think FICO use of brand when it comes to scoring in U.S. today. That reflects a much different growth profile. So as I think about USIS general today when it comes to PSol, which will be in the future, that free market is here, and it's clear, we got a great strategy around that and continues to develop right now.

Good day, and welcome to the First Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded. 
At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Mr. Jeff Dodge. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, and good morning. Welcome to today's conference call. I'm Jeff Dodge, Investor Relations, and with me today are Rick Smith, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and John Gamble, Chief Financial Officer. Today's call is being recorded. An archiv
componenttext:
Thanks, and good morning. Welcome to today's conference call. I'm Jeff Dodge, Investor Relations, and with me today are Rick Smith, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and John Gamble, Chief Financial Officer. 
Today's call is being recorded. An archive of the recording will be available later today in the Investor Relations section of the About Equifax tab of our website at www.equifax.com. 
During this call, we'll be making certain forward-looking statements to help you understand Equifax and its business environment. These statements involve a number of risks, uncertainties and other factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from our expectations. Certain risk factors inherent in our business are set forth in our filings with the SEC, including our 2014 Form 10-K and subsequent filings. 
We will be referring to certain non-GAAP financial measures, including adjusted EPS attributable to Equifax and adjusted operating margin that will be adjusted for certain items, which affect the comparability of the underlying operational performance. Adjusted EPS attributable to Equifax excludes acquisition-related amortization expense and the associated tax effects and a charge principally related to the realignment of internal resources to more effectively support the company's strategic objectives. Adjusted operating margin excludes the onetime charge principally related to the realignment of our internal resources. These measures are detailed in our non-GAAP reconciliation tables included in our earnings release and also posted on our website. Also, please refer to our various investor presentations, which are posted in the Investor Relations section of our website, www.equifax -- .investor.equifax.com, for further details. 
Now I'd like to turn it over to Rick.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jeff, and good morning, everyone. As always, thank you for making time for join us this morning. The first quarter's performance was very robust and significantly exceeded our expectations. A theme you'll hear throughout my comments and John's c
componenttext:
Thanks, Jeff, and good morning, everyone. As always, thank you for making time for join us this morning. 
The first quarter's performance was very robust and significantly exceeded our expectations. A theme you'll hear throughout my comments and John's comments and the question-and-answer period will be that the growth for the quarter was very broad based. It was across all business units, across many verticals and across many countries. USIS and Workforce Solutions in particular posted an exceptional quarter. USIS saw strength with its Decision 360 initiatives, enterprise selling strategy, direct-to-consumer channel partners, mortgage and home equity lending. Workforce Solutions saw broad strength in Verification Services, including government, automotive and mortgage, as well as solid strength in its Employer services business. The revenue strength in both those businesses led to nice margin expansions, as you saw. Also, International and PSol finished with very solid performances for the quarter. 
In total, the revenue was $652 million, up 12% on a reported basis, up 14.4% on a local currency basis versus the first quarter of 2014. In the quarter, FX created $17 million of year-over-year headwind, an increase from the fourth quarter of last year, which was $13 million of headwind. The adjusted operating margin was 27.2%, up 120 basis points from the first quarter of 2014. Adjusted EPS was $1.07, up 20% from $0.89 a share last year and significantly above the upper end of the guidance we provided a few months ago. 
And I will walk through some business by business unit highlights, and then John will get into the details of the financials. I'll start, as I always do, with USCIS. There they leverage this -- their Decision 360 initiative, New Product Innovation and enterprise selling teams to deliver 14% revenue growth and a healthy 42.4% operating margin, up 520 basis points from last year. 
Couple of highlights. Our relationship with Credit Karma we talked about in the past, they went live in January and generated transaction volumes exceeding our original predictions -- projections. In addition to purchasing our credit information, Credit Karma is also using our premier fraud and identity authentication solutions to provide consumers with online access to their credit information. Originally, we were part of a 2-Bureau solution with Credit Karma, and we believe this will ultimately move to a 3-Bureau solution in an effort to better maximize the benefits to the consumers. 
As I mentioned last call, in recent quarters, one of the things we're seeing is that the financial institutions are changing the way they originate new consumer accounts. In Financial Marketing Services, FMS, the traditional Prescreen activity are giving away some more targeted one-on-one online offers. We talked about this again in last few quarters. And as a result, our revenue mix as it [indiscernible] been shifting towards higher-margin online solutions, our growth in Prescreen revenues has moderated somewhat. 
Net-net, these had shifted the benefit to USIS. 
As you know, we folded Commercial into USIS a few quarters ago. The Commercial business is off to a great start, recording their best first quarter performance since 2007 with record revenue and operating margin performance. 
Mortgage origination and home equity lending were also stronger in the quarter as low interest rate environment resulted in lending activity that exceeded our expectations for the quarter. And we'll get into that in the Q&A and compare it to the MBA. 
Our core tri-bureau reporting volume was up 18%, and we're also experiencing -- experienced strong growth in our high-value Undisclosed Debt Monitoring product services as lenders continued to move -- continued with their more rigorous underwriting standards. 
The pace of mortgage refinancing activity in home equity lending continues to be solid, and we expect it will moderate, as we talked about back in February, somewhat going into second quarter and then continue to moderate as we exit the year. USIS growth rate is expected to be strong over the course of the year and be comfortably above its long-term growth range of 5% to 7% for the full year. 
On the International, they posted a double-digit local currency growth in 5 countries, including the U.K., continue to make good progress with the integration of TDX, which delivered constant currency revenue growth in excess of 25% for the first quarter. And they're also leveraging NPI further, their market position, as many products delivered revenue above their expectation for the quarter around the world. International's ongoing effort to diversify its revenue base is underscored by double-digit constant currency growth from their SME customer base, retail customers, insurance customers, government customers and utility customers around the globe. Also, all verticals, including financial, our decision and analytics solutions, are strengthening relationships with our customers and opening new opportunities to NPI and new sources of growth going forward. 
International's operating margin performance is also improving. Excluding TDX and all the investments we're making in TDX, International's operating margin expanded by approximately 190 basis points in the quarter when compared to the first quarter of 2014. 
During the quarter, we executed a debt recovery services contract with Her Majesty's government in the U.K. that we talked about last time. That's resulting in continued investment in TDX as we prepare to ramp up and go live sometime in late third quarter for this multiyear U.K. government opportunity. So net-net, that opportunity is on pace and on track on almost every dimension. And again, we expect some modest revenue at the back end of this year, further ramping up in 2014 (sic) [2016]. 
In addition, the unique capabilities of TDX and also Inffinix, that's the one what we bought in Mexico, those capabilities are being leveraged in other geographic markets where we do not personally [ph] have credit information operating units. 
This year, International will be launching a Latin American regionalization strategy, that's what Jeff kind of alluded to, that includes people, process and system changes. This effort will further streamline our operations and provide incremental operating leverage for International and also improve customer service and accelerate our time to revenue for New Product Innovation. 
For the year, we expect revenue growth to be solidly in the long-term range of 7% to 10% growth for International with improving -- improved operating margins as we exit the year. 
On to EWS. Their momentum accelerated in the quarter, a remarkable performance, with broad-based revenue growth of 24%, up from 15% growth in the fourth quarter, and margins were up an astonishing 800 basis points from the first quarter of last year to 40.3% for the quarter. Verification Services continued to make great progress penetrating our targeted non-mortgage markets. They delivered strong double-digit growth in home equity lending, auto, car, consumer finance, government and pre-employment. And finally, growth in our mortgage activity drove a very healthy 34% growth in overall Verification Services revenue. In addition, our penetration of peer-to-peer lending space with our employment and income verification services had delivered strong new sources of growth. 
We now have over 4,500 companies contributing their employment and income information into The Work Number database, and this number of companies are growing on a monthly basis. 
The outlook for 2015 continues to be very good. Although mortgage originations are expected to slow, our revenues from various ACA initiatives, further penetration of employment and income verification in non-mortgage markets and our strategic initiatives in Employer Services are expected to offset the mortgage decrease later this year, resulting in full year revenue growth well above the top end of the multiyear range and margin expansion in the range or the neighborhood of 350 basis points or more versus 2014. 
On to PSol. Constant currency revenue growth was at the upper end of the multiyear range and operating margins continued to be strong. In addition, they're making good progress on their strategic transformation. Double-digit growth in indirect Canada and U.K. were the major contributors to growth in the quarter. For our direct-to-consumer activities in the U.S., the key operating metric, average revenue per subscriber and churn, continue to improve. 
2015 will be a good transformational year for PSol, as we talked about in the past. They are making good progress on 3 fronts: strengthening the core U.S.-based business; number two, developing a strong market position in the indirect space; and three, growing our international presence in Canada and the U.K. We expect Personal Solutions to end the year with revenue growing comfortably within our multiyear target range. 
Let me go back to corporate and I'll give you some highlights at the corporate level and then turn it over to John for the financials. 
You've all heard us I think we've spent about 9 years now talking about how NPI drives growth. In fact, we've talked about 3 points of growth coming from NPI, and NPI delivered those 3 points of growth for us in the first quarter. There's another very important growth driver, which we launched about 3 or 4 years ago we don't talk a lot about. And we launched it across all of our business units, and that's what we call enterprise growth initiatives, EGI for us. It's a very systematic way for managing multimillion dollar revenue initiatives that we overwhelm with resources and process and senior management attention because of their importance to our long-term growth. Now our EGI initiatives had a banner first quarter performance with strong double-digit growth, exceeding our expectations for the quarter, and our outlook for the year continues to be for very strong year-on-year growth coming from EGI. 
Also, at the corporate level, we've been talking about how we've developed a strong reputation with our customers regarding our expertise in LEAN, and we're doing this globally. We're not only leveraging relationships with our existing customers by continuing to drive incremental revenue growth, but we're also opening doors with non-customers around the world because of the reputation we've developed in some of our very key verticals. It gives us yet another opportunity to grow revenue through strong customer partnerships and really differentiate our offerings to these customers in yet another dimension. Our global fraud initiatives, which cross our all of our BU -- all of our B2B business units, delivered double-digit growth in the quarter as well. 
In summary, the quarter's performance is the strongest first quarter performance we've experienced in many years. Sequential revenue growth in the fourth quarter was up 4.4%, whereas in the past years we would typically experience modest or even declining sequential growth. Adjusted operating margin expanded 70 basis points from the fourth quarter, and adjusted earnings per share increased almost 5% from the fourth quarter when we usually see declining sequential growth. Despite this unprecedented performance, we're still early in the year and there are still some uncertainties out there and macroeconomic challenges around the globe. However, we are more optimistic now than we were when we entered the year. 
I'll turn over to you, John, now for some financials and I'll come back with some closing comments.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rick, and good morning, everyone. As before, I'll be referring to the financial results from continuing operations generally presented on a GAAP basis. Now during the quarter, we recorded a charge of $23.4 million principally related to the real
componenttext:
Thanks, Rick, and good morning, everyone. As before, I'll be referring to the financial results from continuing operations generally presented on a GAAP basis. 
Now during the quarter, we recorded a charge of $23.4 million principally related to the realignment of internal resources to more effectively support our strategic objectives. The actions were primarily driven by the regionalization and consolidation strategies in International, including the integration of TDX; consolidation of functions related to the integration of Commercial into USIS; and then the -- some realignment actions across the remainder of the business. The costs were 2/3 severance but also include related real estate, legal and other costs. The costs are reflected in SG&A and the general corporate expense lines of our financial statements. The actions will occur throughout 2015 and should be completed within 12 months. Ongoing savings, once the actions are complete, are expected to be $10 million to $15 million per year with limited incremental benefit in 2015. 
Now consistent with our past practice for treating unusual or infrequent items, we have excluded this charge from our adjusted EPS and adjusted operating margin in order to provide investors with a more consistent period-to-period operating comparison. The FX impact on revenue and EPS this quarter were consistent with our expectations that we provided to you in February. 
Now let me turn to the business units' financial performance for the quarter. U.S. Information Solutions revenue was $299 million, up 14% when compared to the first quarter. Online Information Solutions revenue was $222 million, up 15% when compared to the year-ago period. Mortgage Solutions revenue was $31 million, up 28% compared to Q1 2014. These trends compare favorably to the Mortgage Bankers Application Index, which was up 21% in the first quarter. Financial Marketing Services revenue was $46 million, up 3% when compared to the year-ago quarter. As Rick mentioned earlier, the slower growth reflects a shift in how financial institutions are originating new accounts to 1:1 online solicitations. 
The operating margin for U.S. Information Solutions was 42.4%, up from 37.2% in the first quarter of 2013. We continue to expect USIS to have operating margins in the low 40s, consistent with our long-term model in 2015. 
International's revenue was $139 million, down 1% on a reported basis but up 10% on a local currency basis. By region, Europe's revenue was $58 million, up 1% in U.S. dollars and up 12% in local currency. Latin America's revenue was $48 million, up 2% in U.S. dollars and 13% in local currency. Canada revenue was $33 million, down 9% in U.S. dollars but up 3% in local currency. 
For the first quarter, International's operating margin was 20.2%, down slightly from 20.6% in the first quarter of 2014. This reduction in margin was principally due to FX. For the full year, we continue to expect the operating margin to expand slightly compared to 2014. 
Workforce Solutions revenue was $149 million for the quarter, up 24% when compared to the first quarter of 2014. Verification Services with revenue of $86 million was up 34% when compared to the same quarter in 2014. Employer Services revenue was $63 million, up 13% compared to last year. Following the WOTC hiatus in 2014, states began processing their backlog during the first quarter. Also, revenue from our ACA analytical solutions was very strong in the quarter. The Workforce Solutions operating margin was 40.3% compared to 32.3% in Q1 of 2014. The margin benefited from the WOTC Renewal, which contributed approximately 3 percentage points to the margin in the quarter. For full year 2015, we continue to expect Workforce Solutions operating margin to be in the range of 36% to 37%. 
Personal Solutions revenue was $66 million, up 4% on a reported basis and up 6% on a local currency basis. For the first quarter, operating margin was 27.4% compared to 28.5% in Q1 2014. This year-over-year reduction is consistent with our expectations and the guidance we gave for Q1 and the full year. 
In the first quarter, general corporate expense at $78.4 million was up significantly, reflecting the $23.4 million realignment charge I mentioned previously. Excluding this charge, general corporate expense was $55 million, up $8.7 million sequentially and $24.3 million versus 1Q '15 -- versus 1Q '14. This increase was principally due to increased incentive and equity compensation and benefits expense. This reflects the very strong performance in 1Q '15 as well as earlier timing of annual equity expense in 2015 versus 2014. We also saw increased professional, legal and regulatory costs in 1Q '15 versus 1Q '14. Looking at 2Q '15, we expect general corporate expense to be down $10 million sequentially on an adjusted basis, reflecting lower equity expense and at or slightly below the Q2 level in both Q3 and Q4. 
Operating cash flow was $103 million in the first quarter. Cash flow grew faster than earnings, reflecting positive working capital performance. We continued our aggressive stock buyback activity, repurchasing 1 million shares for $90 million and paid $35 million in dividends to our shareholders. 
Our leverage remains a very conservative 1.75x EBITDA. 
Now let me turn it back to Rick.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. Thanks, John. A quick outlook for guidance for the second quarter and the total year. Before I give you some numbers, I just want to put into perspective the influence of the mortgage market as it relates to the second quarter and the balance of th
componenttext:
Great. Thanks, John. A quick outlook for guidance for the second quarter and the total year. Before I give you some numbers, I just want to put into perspective the influence of the mortgage market as it relates to the second quarter and the balance of the year. Again, we expect the market to -- the mortgage market to perform much like we talked about back in February, moderating a bit in the second quarter and then continuing to moderate even further year-on-year in the third and fourth quarter. 
So for the second quarter, we expect organic revenue growth -- organic revenue to be between $655 million and $665 million. That is a constant currency organic revenue growth rate of 10% to 12%, and it's partially offset by 3 points of FX headwind. 
Adjusted EPS is expected to be between $1.09 and $1.11, which is up 14% to 16%, excluding $0.02 per share of negative impact from FX. This reflects  constant currency growth rate of 16% to 18% for the quarter. 
We also expect operating margin to continue to improve and end the quarter in the range of 27.5% to 28%. 
Obviously, there's some uncertainty for the balance of the year. Its macroeconomic uncertainty around the world and it's U.S. economic uncertainty, some uncertainty in the Middle East, uncertainty in Latin America. So -- but against that uncertain backdrop, I'm convinced that this team will continue to execute extremely well and continue driving above-market growth across all of our businesses and all of our verticals through the second quarter and the balance of the year. 
So with that and based upon the current level of domestic and International business activity and the FX rates, we expect 2015 to have revenue in the range of $2.585 billion to $2.635 billion, which is up from our previous guidance. This reflects constant currency organic revenue growth of 8% to 11% for the year. The strong revenue growth is partially offset by 3 points of negative impact from FX. And again, as before, this is only organic revenue growth at this time. 
2015 adjusted EPS, we expect to be in the range of $4.28 and $4.35 per share, also up from our previous guidance. This reflects 10% to 12% growth in 2015. 
FX impact for the year, as we previously stated in the last earnings call, is expected to be about $0.11 for the year, and we have a -- 11% for the year -- $0.11 for the year. We have a $0.02 a share impact in the first quarter, which says we have a remaining $0.09 per share impact for the full year. 
So with that, operator, let's open up for any questions you might have.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll go to Shlomo Rosenbaum with Stifel.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll go to Shlomo Rosenbaum with Stifel.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I want to just drill in a little bit more. A very, very healthy growth across the company. The biggest, I would say, surprise was on the Employer Services that has had the best growth, it looked like, in like 5 years. Can you talk a little bit about just
componenttext: I want to just drill in a little bit more. A very, very healthy growth across the company. The biggest, I would say, surprise was on the Employer Services that has had the best growth, it looked like, in like 5 years. Can you talk a little bit about just stuff that came together specifically in the quarter and how I should be thinking about the growth? Have you gotten it through a sustainable double-digit growth level over there? How should I think about that?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Shlomo. I'd say there's 2 primary drivers to the growth. One, I think I mentioned it last year, we've got new leadership and it's been there about 1 year or so, 1.5 years. Scott Collins has been doing a heck of a job. You see it's a mentality out
componenttext: Thanks, Shlomo. I'd say there's 2 primary drivers to the growth. One, I think I mentioned it last year, we've got new leadership and it's been there about 1 year or so, 1.5 years. Scott Collins has been doing a heck of a job. You see it's a mentality out there from a business unit that's kind of a protect The Work Number to a growth business model. So he has built processes, he is changing the team. They think about growth and not protect. So that's helping. And then you had a -- the WOTC benefit for the first quarter that added some growth as well. So as I think about the Verification Services piece of EWS, Shlomo, when we bought the business, we thought it would be a good solid year-on-year middle-single-digit kind of growth rate. So I would not model a double-digit growth rate for Verification -- or for Employer Services at this time.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: So if I take it further down, how much of that was like ACA work and some of the stuff that's just compliance-type work that's going to be sustainable going forward?
componenttext: So if I take it further down, how much of that was like ACA work and some of the stuff that's just compliance-type work that's going to be sustainable going forward?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, there -- I mean, in the Employer Services, there's a piece of business that is on fire, and I think we talked about it in the last earnings call. And that is the -- what we call Workforce Analytics. And that is -- kind of grew over 100% this year, an
componenttext: Yes, there -- I mean, in the Employer Services, there's a piece of business that is on fire, and I think we talked about it in the last earnings call. And that is the -- what we call Workforce Analytics. And that is -- kind of grew over 100% this year, and we've -- we're signing hundreds of contracts to help employers make sure they're compliant with the ACA laws. And remember, as I mentioned before, Shlomo, we get multiple bites of the apples there. You get some consulting revenue, you get the analytics revenue. And in many cases, the employers who are using that analytics don't give us Work Number records that we can analyze their level of compliance as they get Work Number records. So that revenue growth, by adding those records to the revenue base, don't show up in Employer. It shows up in Verification once we load it on the system. So you should consider ACA analytics or Workforce Analytics as being a long-term, sustainable growth piece of EWS' strategy. Also, within the Employer Services, they're building out a really good full suite of compliance-centric products to help our employers ensure they're compliant with many regulatory changes, not just before we'll carry that.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: So do you feel -- I mean, how much are you able to quantify or give a rough estimate as to kind of that virtuous circle of doing that type of compliance that's resulting in The Work, right, The Work Number, and then additional hits to the database that ar
componenttext: So do you feel -- I mean, how much are you able to quantify or give a rough estimate as to kind of that virtuous circle of doing that type of compliance that's resulting in The Work, right, The Work Number, and then additional hits to the database that are coming back with some things that's adding revenue to the Verification Services side?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Rest assured we do know those numbers. We don't disclose those right now. But if you talk to Dann Adams, Shlomo, he would tell you, as would Scott, again, one, it's that part of the business won, that the Compliance Center is a exciting multiyear growth s
componenttext: Rest assured we do know those numbers. We don't disclose those right now. But if you talk to Dann Adams, Shlomo, he would tell you, as would Scott, again, one, it's that part of the business won, that the Compliance Center is a exciting multiyear growth strategy for EWS in total and clearly for the employer side. We've given you some color in the past around the number of records added through ACA -- or through Workforce Analytics, and you know the number on the average revenue per transaction. So you can build some sense of how important that is on the Verification side. It's meaningful.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: And just one last question and I'll drop off. How much did the Credit Karma relationship add to the year-over-year growth in the OCIS?
componenttext: And just one last question and I'll drop off. How much did the Credit Karma relationship add to the year-over-year growth in the OCIS?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015

componenttext: We don't disclose individual client activity. We've given you a number, I think it was back in the fourth quarter, on what it would be. We said $20 million to $25 million a year in revenue. So in the scheme of things for the company, a great customer, a great win. Not overly significant for the company but important for USIS.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015

componenttext: Yes. Again, as I tried to allude to -- in the -- my opening comments and as John in his, it is extremely broad based. It is. Automotive was extremely strong. Our KCP clients were strong. Financial services were strong. Telco was strong. Credit Karma was strong. Mortgage channel partners were strong. It is extremely broad based.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: And just as a follow-up, your 450 basis points of operating margin expansion in that business, do you have a higher target now for operating leverage in that business? Or is this short-term strength that will slow over time?
componenttext: And just as a follow-up, your 450 basis points of operating margin expansion in that business, do you have a higher target now for operating leverage in that business? Or is this short-term strength that will slow over time?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: The gift that keeps on giving. You always want more, David. I'd say the beauty of this model is we have the ability to continue to invest in CapEx for organic growth. And as you're growing, the numbers you get is phenomenal. And that exists not only in US
componenttext: The gift that keeps on giving. You always want more, David. I'd say the beauty of this model is we have the ability to continue to invest in CapEx for organic growth. And as you're growing, the numbers you get is phenomenal. And that exists not only in USIS. As you saw, that exists in virtually every business we have. I mean, what you just saw in EWS as well. So yes, I think now that they're over -- I don't know the exact number for USIS but over 42%, I think it was, yes, you should expect them to be in that range and continue -- the only way, John and I can give you our targeted 25 basis points of expansion year-over-year is if every business unit continues to grow. So I expect USIS to continue to expand their margins as well.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Final question for me on capital allocation. What should we think about in the next year in terms of dividend growth given the elevated EPS growth that you showed in the first quarter?
componenttext: Final question for me on capital allocation. What should we think about in the next year in terms of dividend growth given the elevated EPS growth that you showed in the first quarter?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we're committed to that range that we talked about. I think it was 3 or 4 years ago when we established the dividend policy of 25% to 35% of our net income, and that's in the form of a dividend. So as we continue to grow net income, you should conti
componenttext: Well, we're committed to that range that we talked about. I think it was 3 or 4 years ago when we established the dividend policy of 25% to 35% of our net income, and that's in the form of a dividend. So as we continue to grow net income, you should continue to expect dividends will increase.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll go to Manav Patnaik with Barclays.
componenttext: We'll go to Manav Patnaik with Barclays.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is actually Greg calling in for Manav. I just wanted to kind of dig in a little bit on the TDX contract with the U.K. government. Clearly, you guys sound pretty constructive about it. But I was hoping to get some color both around the magnitude of th
componenttext: This is actually Greg calling in for Manav. I just wanted to kind of dig in a little bit on the TDX contract with the U.K. government. Clearly, you guys sound pretty constructive about it. But I was hoping to get some color both around the magnitude of the cost as you ramp up that contract and then how to think about the ramp-up and the ultimate opportunity there.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Greg, thanks for joining. I'll talk specifically about TDX. What you can hear us talk about more in the future is a debt services platform which is really integrating the capabilities we have in our Mexican acquisition, it's about the same time frame
componenttext: Yes, Greg, thanks for joining. I'll talk specifically about TDX. What you can hear us talk about more in the future is a debt services platform which is really integrating the capabilities we have in our Mexican acquisition, it's about the same time frame, called Inffinix, and then TDX, which is the U.K.-domiciled capability. So you'll hear us talk about a kind of just debt servicing platform versus TDX or Inffinix going forward. Specific to the Her Majesty's contract, as I alluded to briefly in my comments, it's going as expected. We've overwhelmed this with people, with process. The timeline was tight. It was such a significant award that we had to make sure we got it right and we're getting it right. And the hope is we stand this technical environment up, this structure up in third quarter, and we start to receive their first load of data in the third quarter. It takes you a while to analyze the data, understand the data, format the data. And then you pass that -- the analytics on to the collection agencies across the country. So that's why I said you expect a nominal amount of revenue in the 2015 year, maybe the very end of the fourth quarter, and then ramping up nicely in 2016.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I guess along that same theme, during -- post the acquisition, you talked a lot about bringing the TDX capabilities to new markets, whether it's the U.S. or Australia. Does this contract put that a little bit on the back burner? Or how are you s
componenttext: Okay. And I guess along that same theme, during -- post the acquisition, you talked a lot about bringing the TDX capabilities to new markets, whether it's the U.S. or Australia. Does this contract put that a little bit on the back burner? Or how are you seeing that progress right now?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's a great question. It did a little bit early on because the same teams can build the capabilities they deploy in different countries. We're consumed [ph]. We're getting the DMI [ph] contract up and running in the U.K. How -- we're going to tell you
componenttext: That's a great question. It did a little bit early on because the same teams can build the capabilities they deploy in different countries. We're consumed [ph]. We're getting the DMI [ph] contract up and running in the U.K. How -- we're going to tell you it's been moving full speed now in places like Canada. I was just in South America last week, met with clients in both Chile and Argentina. The interest level is extremely high. The pipeline is very good. Things are going very well in Australia. As we mentioned before, things are going very well improving in Peru, Colombia. There's a strong interest in Brazil for the platform. So it -- while we're distracted a little bit with DMI [ph], that distraction is now behind. We'll run at full speed.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll go to Andrew Jeffrey with SunTrust.
componenttext: We'll go to Andrew Jeffrey with SunTrust.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Rick, I guess kind of a 2-part question. One, from a big-picture perspective in terms of where we are in the credit cycle, I heard you mention a lot of consumer credit products save credit cards. So I wonder if you have a sense as to where you think we ar
componenttext: Rick, I guess kind of a 2-part question. One, from a big-picture perspective in terms of where we are in the credit cycle, I heard you mention a lot of consumer credit products save credit cards. So I wonder if you have a sense as to where you think we are as far as issuers ramping up their consumer credit card businesses. And then sort of as a corollary, you mentioned the shift in the way your customers are going to market, and I wonder how that dovetails with some of the newer credit modeling solutions that FICO is introducing around thin files and perhaps how that might open up sort of the next leg of growth in consumer credit cycle or whether you think it will at all.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Andrew. Two thoughts. One, on the Bancard issuance, what's going on there. Since the Bancard issuance in the U.S. kind of hit the bottom, the market has rebounded at a rate of about 10% or so a year. So it's growing modestly -- actually above mode
componenttext: Thanks, Andrew. Two thoughts. One, on the Bancard issuance, what's going on there. Since the Bancard issuance in the U.S. kind of hit the bottom, the market has rebounded at a rate of about 10% or so a year. So it's growing modestly -- actually above modestly. However, it still remains significantly below the pre-recessionary levels. So improving but nowhere close to where we were back in the pre-recessionary environment. And obviously, that improvement helps us. As far as FICO, as you know, the FICO municipal thin score -- thin file score you alluded to is predicated largely upon our data and Elan's data. Well, the data they use in that model is borrowing the data from our -- and we use NCT [ph] reports, the positive credit file on utilities and telcos. So as that product takes off, obviously we're a benefactor of that.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Do you think from a macro perspective that this signals -- the move towards thin file scoring and so forth signals a sort of an opening up of the underwriting environment? Or is this a more sort of tactical or a more incremental, I guess?
componenttext: Okay. Do you think from a macro perspective that this signals -- the move towards thin file scoring and so forth signals a sort of an opening up of the underwriting environment? Or is this a more sort of tactical or a more incremental, I guess?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it's more incremental. If you look at the -- take a proxy, the subprime Bancard market. What you're seeing there is yes, they're getting a little more aggressive in subprime lending, but the outstanding -- that alone -- the limits, I should s
componenttext: Yes, I think it's more incremental. If you look at the -- take a proxy, the subprime Bancard market. What you're seeing there is yes, they're getting a little more aggressive in subprime lending, but the outstanding -- that alone -- the limits, I should say, are extremely low. And so while they're going a little more aggressive, and obviously the thin file score will help them be even more aggressive, they're being very cautious on the limits they're applying to those Bancards. But obviously, anytime you can give more people access to credit and the score does that, we benefit by default.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, okay. No, that's helpful. And then just as a follow-up, you mentioned -- you called out EGI as a driver. Is -- could you just give a couple of examples? And I wonder if you move toward more of these enterprise solutions, that's helping your pricing
componenttext: Sure, okay. No, that's helpful. And then just as a follow-up, you mentioned -- you called out EGI as a driver. Is -- could you just give a couple of examples? And I wonder if you move toward more of these enterprise solutions, that's helping your pricing overall.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Great -- well, yes. So Andrew, you -- I think you may know we are [indiscernible] guy whose name Andy Bodea. Works from a -- he runs global operations, runs our global LEAN, global procurement. He is a great operator, a disciplined operator. And he's
componenttext: Yes. Great -- well, yes. So Andrew, you -- I think you may know we are [indiscernible] guy whose name Andy Bodea. Works from a -- he runs global operations, runs our global LEAN, global procurement. He is a great operator, a disciplined operator. And he's got a great team around him. We're still looking at this in earnest maybe 3 or 4 years ago and said we've got these large, multimillion dollar, sometimes across business unit deals. It needs more rigor to ensure out time to revenue is as expected, much like we did in NPI. So Andy and his team have been doing this now for 3 or 4 years. And we're doing stuff. I'll give a couple of examples of where we're attacking EGI today. One is in automotive, and we're couple of years into that now. And we decided we -- to get in automotive heavily, we'll leverage EGI just to do so. Another I learned through EWS a few minutes ago was this Compliance Center, building up more capabilities other than just INI [ph] and W-2 and some others in ACA Workforce Analytics. The whole suite of new products. Obviously, in that one there, we don't see things in PSol with the new platform and PSol's go-to-market. So does it give you explicitly pricing power? It definitely gives you revenue growth, which is a factor in our performance, as you've seen, as we exited 2014 and continue in 2015. I think anytime you can build products that differentiate what you do versus your competition, it does -- you add more value. The discussion goes away from pricing and more to share gains [indiscernible].

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll go to George Mihalos with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: We'll go to George Mihalos with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Rick and John, I just wanted to start off with if we look at the first quarter, you did, I think, 14% constant currency of organic revenue growth. The outlook for the second quarter, I think you're talking about 10% to 12% constant currency. Is there anyt
componenttext: Rick and John, I just wanted to start off with if we look at the first quarter, you did, I think, 14% constant currency of organic revenue growth. The outlook for the second quarter, I think you're talking about 10% to 12% constant currency. Is there anything outside of any sort of variability on the mortgage side that would cause you to expect that deceleration, I guess, or anything going on in the business that you think was sort of onetime in the first quarter or that is slowing a little bit as you go through the back half of the year outside of mortgage?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, it's specific to the second quarter, and I'll come back to the balance of the year. There are 2 primary drivers when you look at sequential growth. And you got one, George, which is the mortgage market. And the other is, I think I alluded to it in my
componenttext: No, it's specific to the second quarter, and I'll come back to the balance of the year. There are 2 primary drivers when you look at sequential growth. And you got one, George, which is the mortgage market. And the other is, I think I alluded to it in my comments, the WOTC contract. We'll push up any tax credit contract which we monetized in the first quarter this year. We did last year as well. It doesn't repeat. It's -- really, it's a 1-quarter -- largely a 1-quarter activity. So that's the nuances, if you will, for the second quarter. And then for the balance of the year, the third and fourth quarter, when you look at growth rate [ph], which is still very solid, I think you'd agree, it's really the uncertainty on a macro basis: interest rate environment, regulatory environment around the world, economic environment, so on and so forth, geopolitical issues. And there's uncertainty there. That's about it.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. Appreciate the color. And then as it relates to margins on International and sort of the rollout of TDX there, it sounds like the contract will sort of be somewhat fully ramped in the fourth quarter. I appreciate the commentary around margins
componenttext: Okay, great. Appreciate the color. And then as it relates to margins on International and sort of the rollout of TDX there, it sounds like the contract will sort of be somewhat fully ramped in the fourth quarter. I appreciate the commentary around margins in International for the year, but what is sort of a good exit rate ending '15 for International margins? I would imagine they'll sort of they spike up in the fourth quarter. Is that a fair way to think about it?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, no, because they -- as I alluded to, the data that will come in for the third quarter actually formatted, analyze it and then start to distribute the data and analytics, it's going to wait fourth quarter. So I don't expect much revenue. It's not a l
componenttext: Well, no, because they -- as I alluded to, the data that will come in for the third quarter actually formatted, analyze it and then start to distribute the data and analytics, it's going to wait fourth quarter. So I don't expect much revenue. It's not a large contract. You got to understand, the investment we made in this business has been on 2 fronts. One is standing up DMI [ph], and the other is the typical stuff we invest in when we acquire a company and add security. That's compliance. We're in the process of applying for a license in U.K. for this organization and so on and so forth just to make sure it's fully, fully [indiscernible]. So this is a year of fairly heavy, broad-based investment in TDX, also investment to make it -- to run a global -- in more countries. So as far as margin experiences for TDX specifically and then International, I expect modest improvement for International for this year but then more significant improvement as we go in 2016 because the level of spend comes down, the core TDX business continues to grow strong at double digits and the monetization of DMI [ph].

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And just last question for me. As it relates to the restructuring savings, the $10 million to $15 million, would you expect that to fully sort of pass through in '16? Or is the expectation that you'll reinvest those savings in the business fo
componenttext: Okay, great. And just last question for me. As it relates to the restructuring savings, the $10 million to $15 million, would you expect that to fully sort of pass through in '16? Or is the expectation that you'll reinvest those savings in the business for accelerated growth?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: John?
componenttext: John?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would expect probably it's a combination of both, right? Some of it we'll pass through, and then some of it we'll reinvest to further accelerate growth in '16 and '17. So you're going to see a combination of both actually.
componenttext: I would expect probably it's a combination of both, right? Some of it we'll pass through, and then some of it we'll reinvest to further accelerate growth in '16 and '17. So you're going to see a combination of both actually.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
