headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, and welcome to the second quarter 2015 earnings call. Today's conference is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Jeff Dodge. Please go ahead, sir.
componenttext:
Good day, and welcome to the second quarter 2015 earnings call. Today's conference is being recorded. 
At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Jeff Dodge. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, and good morning. Welcome to today's conference call. I am Jeff Dodge, Investor Relations, and with me today are Rick Smith, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and John Gamble, Chief Financial Officer. Today's call is being recorded. An archi
componenttext:
Thanks, and good morning. Welcome to today's conference call. I am Jeff Dodge, Investor Relations, and with me today are Rick Smith, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and John Gamble, Chief Financial Officer. 
Today's call is being recorded. An archive of the recording will be available later today in the Investor Relations section of the About Equifax tab of our website at www.equifax.com. During this call, we'll be making certain forward-looking statements to help you understand Equifax and its business environment. These statements involve a number of risks, uncertainties and other factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from our expectations. Certain risk factors inherent in our business are set forth in our filings with the SEC, including our 2014 Form 10-K and subsequent filings. 
We will be referring to certain non-GAAP financial measures, including adjusted EPS attributable to Equifax that will be adjusted for certain items, which affect the comparability of the underlying operational performance. Adjusted EPS attributable to Equifax excludes acquisition-related amortization expense and the associated tax effects, an impairment charge related to our cost method investment in BBS and an income tax benefit generated from the state tax law change. These measures are detailed in our non-GAAP reconciliation tables included with our earnings release and also posted on our website. Also, please refer to our various investor presentations, which are posted in the Investor Relations section of our website, www.investor.equifax.com, for further details. 
Now I'd like to turn it over to Rick.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jeff. Good morning, everyone. Thanks, as always, for joining us this morning. By now you've seen the results and you can agree our company continues to benefit from our unique and very diversified business model, also benefits from our high level
componenttext:
Thanks, Jeff. Good morning, everyone. Thanks, as always, for joining us this morning. By now you've seen the results and you can agree our company continues to benefit from our unique and very diversified business model, also benefits from our high level of execution across all the BUs in the Centers of Excellences, and we continue to reap benefits from the new product innovation that we've launched back in 2006. The quarter, both revenue and adjusted EPS, exceeded the upper end of our guidance range of 4 business units, and they grew revenue growth ahead of our expectations. This reflected both our continued execution of new products and market expansions as well as a stronger-than-expected U.S. mortgage market. 
Total revenue for the quarter was $678 million, up 10% on a reported basis and up 14% on a local currency basis from the second quarter of 2014. In the quarter, FX created a $19 million year-on-year headwind, up from the headwind we experienced in the first quarter of $17 million. Operating margin for the quarter was 27.8%, up from 27.3% in the second quarter of 2014. Adjusted EPS was $1.15, up 20% from $0.96 [ph] a share last year and significantly above the upper end of our guidance range. As always, before John gives you some finish details, I'll go through the some of the business unit highlights as well as some of the corporate highlights and I'll go into the details of the financials with John. 
The power of our Decision 360 initiative, which you by now or are very well aware of, combined with our enterprise selling strategy and our mortgage market success enabled USIS to once again deliver very strong, broad-based 12% growth. Our recently launched data and analytics environment, which we've introduced to you and we call it Cambrian has positioned us to develop and deliver new D360 products at speed that once took weeks now take us minutes. This is something you will recall we've talked about now for probably 2 years, and that is now fully introduction in the U.S. and making a big difference. The primary goal of Cambrian is the source and integrate structured and unstructured data from any industrially anywhere in the world and proactively deliver action and insights valued by our customers. What's particularly compelling is that we can now create transformational solutions like combining traditional, trusted data with other Big Data sources and cutting-edge analytical capabilities with greater ease and speed. Cambrian will help us discover new data assets for our research and/or partnerships that will further broaden and deepen our portfolio of data assets and fuel new product innovation. Personally for Cambrian, the environment is focused on our U.S.-based data assets and market opportunities. However, as we've talked in the past, we'll be developing significant domain expertise that will enable us to expand into our International geographies over the next 6 to 12 months. 
Moving on in the auto vertical in the U.S. we recently launched the first of 3 products in the power lead suite, which leverages our data assets to help auto dealers be more effective in their marketing activities and leverage third-party service providers or connectors as we call them. We help dealers leverage their website performance by turning anonymous borrowers into known high-quality leads. Consumers are now more empowered by getting their credit score online after being authenticated with our eID Verifier services, and all this information is with the consumer authorization and then shared with the dealers. Our partnership with Credit Karma, I think we've talked to you about that back in the very end of 2013, nearly 2014. That continues to be -- '14, '15, very end of '14, sorry about that, that continues to be a very important driver contributor to USIS and is also a great start this year. We now expect the revenue and relationship with Credit Karma for 2015 to exceed our original expectations. 
Explaining the USIS in the utility sector, we launched the first of our 4 market-specific insight tools, leveraging third-party data alongside our credit information in our telco and utility database. These insights will help utilities optimize their deposit strategies to better manage and control portfolio loss rates. 
Our Commercial Solutions business within USIS, the product offerings and business unit had a very strong performance in the quarter, with both accelerating revenue growth and improved operating margins when compared to the first quarter of the year. Mortgage origination activity exceeded our expectations for the quarter and driven by our strong market position, contributed nicely to USIS' growth and margin expansion. Our fraud and property valuations product offerings continue to deliver very strong double-digit growth in the mortgage market as well. We'll talk on these in the Q&A more about mortgage and where that's headed. 
Finally, our partnership with [indiscernible] which we talked to you about in the past, has secured first mobile commerce authentication service with a major telco. The application includes validation of an end-user's photo ID, along with facial biometrics, a first for us. While we expect the mortgage growth to decelerate for the remainder of the year, we expect USIS 2 end 2015 with double-digit organic revenue growth and operating margins comfortably exceeding 40%. 
So on to International. They continue to make very good progress on their critical strategic growth initiatives, including the integration of TDX, implementation of the U.K. government contract and continue to drive innovation through new products around the globe. Revenue in International's 3 largest verticals, which are the financial institutions, telcos and SMEs grew 13% for the quarter. The decisioning platforms, analytic services and debt management revenue grew 17% for the quarter. 
TDX delivered another quarter of 20%-plus revenue growth, a trend we expect to continue as we move into the third quarter. Also, we are in the process of entering the Canadian and Brazilian markets with TDX products and services. We're also meeting all of our operational commitments within TDX over the U.K. contract we've talked about in the past. Equifax data has been integrated into the TDX workflow and developing the consumer insights and appropriate selection strategies. The IT infrastructure build has been completed, and security penetration testing is largely completed. 20 debt collection agency contracts have been signed after bidding with the U.K. government. And as we've mentioned in the past, we expect this to be operational late fourth quarter, early fourth quarter, a modest revenue this year and ramping up nicely in 2016. 
Moving on Latin America. We've identified opportunities to start up exchanges just like we do in the U.S., where critical data assets are not currently available. We've already received approval in one country and will be finalizing our plans by the end of the year. As you know, the exchanges have been very successful in the U.S. with good margins and good competitive differentiation, helping our customers in ways we couldn't help before. We're really excited about what this might bring the one country successful there bringing to other Latin American countries. 
In Canada, we launched a 6-month pilot for e-commerce site to provide online delivery for our business and consumer credit product offerings. This distribution channel will be very attractive to our SME customers while also addressing a growing market demand in other verticals and potentially other geographies. 
And then we recently signed a global agreement with a large International telecom to create new analytical insights using telecom usage data. Ultimately, analytical insights will be so the financial institutions, retailers and other customers in our served markets to facilitate decisioning on consumers who have limited or low credit information. This partnership is significant for Equifax as a new source of rich data for consumers in Latin America, which is typically a negative-data-only geography. We're starting with at risk awards that are developed from our telecom data to address the painful filing and no debt at the point of acquisition. Over time, we'll expand this beyond the kind of acquisition to other decisioning needs. 
For the full year, we expect the International revenue growth to be solidly in the upper end of their long-term growth range, which is 7% to 10% while we continue to grow -- invest in their long-term growth initiatives. On the Workforce Solutions, they again delivered an outstanding broad-based 23% revenue growth and a operating margin of 38.3%, and then they're doing a great job of executing with precision on their strategic objectives. Revenue from all of our Affordable Care Act initiatives continue to accelerate nicely. And with the recent spring court decision, we anticipate continued strong demand from our product offerings in this area. In our ACA platform solution, which enables companies to know the extent of their compliance with the Affordable Care Act, continued to benefit from very strong interest. We now have contracts with numerous employers who in aggregate now have 10 million employees on their payroll. In June alone, we signed 62 new customer contracts. We're uniquely positioned to add value in the healthcare vertical, and we will be making important investments to drive further long-term revenue growth and market penetration. 
Strong growth in Verification Services was driven by continuing to add records, new records with our database, also double-digit growth in mortgage originations and continued penetration of non-mortgage market verticals. In the quarter, our non-mortgage market verification revenue grew 21%, virtually every vertical growing strong double-digit for the quarter, outstanding performance. Growth in mortgage-related revenues decelerated in the second quarter. It's a trend that will continue for the remainder of the year. However, Workforce Solutions' success on many of the strategic initiatives should continue to drive very [indiscernible] growth for the full year, we now expect revenue growth to be in the upper teens with margin expansion over 2014 of at least 400 basis points to approximately 37%. 
On the PSOL, the PSol's growth exceeded our expectation, driven by double-digit growth in our indirect channels and our International segments in addition to winning 2 bridge contracts. Revenue growth for our direct-to-consumer activities in the U.S. continues to be driven by higher average revenue per subscriber and lower churn. They've been a great job on both [indiscernible] PSol is making good progress on their transformation efforts, and we expect full year organic revenue growth to be at the upper end of a long-term range of 4% to 6% and operating margins for the full year solidly in the range of 25% to 30%. 
So again, before I go to Jon with the financial details, let me give you some highlights at the corporate level quickly things we talked about in the past that are very critical to our existing organic growth. You've heard me talk about NPI 2.0 and you heard me talk about EGI. That's critically important growth initiatives. In NPI 2.0, we developed detailed metrics to better manage our pipeline of opportunities to more effectively allocate our resources and track our success on product launches and to minimize time to revenue. Midway to the year, we're now 10% overall revenue target, so the team is doing a great job of executing again in NPI. Our product growth initiatives, we call the EGI. We were focused on larger, more complex projects where we frequently engage multiple parts of the organization. We also have much bigger impact to the revenue growth. EGI is delivering again 1 to 2 points of revenue growth annually for us. 
In global operations, that continues to make important contributions to our bottom line. Within the operation you've heard us talk about Lean initiatives, which traditionally been used internally. We'll talk a lot about that. However, with increased level of competition and regulatory requirements in many of our industrial verticals, there are many new opportunities for incremental revenue growth, and we leveraged LEAN within our customers' operations. Our global Lean team is now -- are currently engaged with over 20 great customers, helping to drive operational improvements that are critical to their success while adding yet another element of differentiation for our business in the marketplace. So our customers become stronger, more efficient, and it helps us differentiate versus competition and secure incremental revenue. 
On to our fraud and identity management business. They're presently broadening to incorporate biometrics in mobile device resolution. We have partnerships. We're also looking -- taking our more successful products and launching them in other geographies. It's a practice we've done in other parts of the business. Now we're intentionally taking Fraud and ID products in all parts of the world, other geographies where it makes sense. 
In summary, the business is off to a solid start this year, with high levels of execution across many of our strategic initiatives. And we're well down the path of changing Equifax from a credit bureau into a truly diversified Information Solutions company. Our domain expertise and analytics and technology enable us to increasing powerful insights to our customers and enhance their decision-making. All of our business units continue to work hard to deliver on their commitments to the company, our customers, employees and shareholders. And as we move into the second half of 2015 and start to look at 2016, I strongly believe the prospects for consumer credit in the developed markets, which we operate, especially the U.S., were very good. The dynamics were shaping up as a sweet spot now for consumer credit growth. 
And with that, let me turn it over to John the financials. John?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rick, and good morning, everyone. As before, I'll be referring to the financial results from continuing operations generally presented on a GAAP basis. During the quarter, we recorded an impairment charge of $14.8 million or $9.8 million after-tax
componenttext:
Thanks, Rick, and good morning, everyone. As before, I'll be referring to the financial results from continuing operations generally presented on a GAAP basis. During the quarter, we recorded an impairment charge of $14.8 million or $9.8 million after-tax related to our cost method investment in BBS. The impairment is, in general, a result of the weakened economic situation in Brazil. We also recorded and $8.6 million after-tax gain due to a state income tax benefit resulting from a state tax law change enacted during the quarter. The net of these 2 unusual items was negative $0.01 per share. Consistent with our past practice for treating unusual or infrequent items, we've excluded items from our adjusted EPS in order to provide investors with a more consistent period-to-period operating comparison. 
Now let me turn to business units' financial performance of for the second quarter. U.S. Information Solutions revenue was $316 million, up 12% when compared to the second quarter of '14. Online Information Solutions revenue was $233 million, up 13% when compared to the year-ago period. Mortgage Solutions revenue was $33 million, up 20% compared to Q2 of 2014. This compares favorably to the Mortgage Bankers Application Index, which was up 16% in the second quarter. Financial Marketing Services revenue was $50 million, up 4% when compared to the year-ago quarter. And the operating margin for U.S. Information Solutions was 42.1%, up from 39.5% in the second quarter of 2014. International revenue was $148 million, down 1% on a reported basis but up 11% on a local currency basis. 
By region, Europe's revenue was $63 million, down 1% in U.S. dollars but up 12% in local currency. Latin America's revenue was $51 million, up 6% in U.S. dollars and 18% in local currency. Canada revenue was $35 million, down 10% in U.S. dollars but up 2% in local currency. For the second quarter, International's operating margin was 19.9%, down from 21.9% in the second quarter of 2014. Although the operating margin fell shorter of our expectations, we have a number of very exciting growth opportunities that were discuss that were incremental investment and management focus. Workforce Solutions revenue was $146 million for the quarter, up 23% when compared to the second quarter of '14. Verification Services, with revenue of $94 million, was up 30% when compared to the same quarter of last year. Employer Services revenue with $52 million, up 11% compared to last year. Growth was aided by ACA analytical solutions and further progress with Compliance Center. The workforce Solutions operating margin was 38.3% compared to 33.9% in Q2 of '14. Personal Solutions revenue was $68 million, up 7% on a reported basis and up 8% on a local currency basis. For the second quarter, operating margin was 27.6% compared to 30.9% in Q2 of 2014. This margin is consistent with our longer-term expectations for this business as it's primarily driven by increased marketing expense during the quarter. 
In the second quarter, general corporate expense at $48.5 million was slightly over the guidance we gave last year. The increase versus our guidance and from the $36.6 million in 2Q of 2014 was principally due to increased incentive compensation expense due to our very strong performance in 2015. We also had increased salaries and benefits and other investment expense primarily related to our key strategic initiatives. 
Looking at the third and fourth quarter, we expect general corporate expense to be approximately $45 million for the quarter, consistent with 2014 levels. Operating margin at 27.8% was very strong. Operating cash flow was $187 million in the quarter. We continue our aggressive stock buyback activity, repurchasing 0.9 million shares for $92 million and paying $34 million in dividends to our shareholders. 
With that, I'll turn it back to Rick.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. Consistent with our guidance last quarter, we expect continued favorable economic conditions in the U.S., spending the majority of our non-mortgage verticals and mortgage in second. International, we expect economic conditions across Europe
componenttext:
Thanks, John. Consistent with our guidance last quarter, we expect continued favorable economic conditions in the U.S., spending the majority of our non-mortgage verticals and mortgage in second. International, we expect economic conditions across Europe and Latin America. And our view of the U.S. mortgage market in the second half of 2015 is roughly consistent with our prior guidance as we expect U.S. mortgage market originations to be up slightly in the second half of 2015 versus the same period in 2014. And we are, however, increasing our full year view for 2015 mortgage originations to be up somewhere between 11% and 13% versus 2014. The U.S. mortgage market was stronger than our expectations in the first half of the year, with originations up approximately 20% versus last year. And again, we'll talk about the nuances and impact moving from refinancing mortgage market to a purchase market, which we're in the process of doing and the benefits that has for our company. 
For the third quarter, we expect revenue -- organic revenue growth to be -- organic revenue to be $655 million and $670 million, reflecting constant currency organic growth between 10% and 12%, partially offset by about 3% FX headwind. Adjusted EPS is expected to be between $1.08 and $1.11 a share, which is up 7% to 10% excluding $0.03 per share of negative impact from FX. This reflects constant currency organic EPS growth of 10% to 15%. We also expect operating margin to be in the range of 27% to 27.5% for the quarter. For the full year, we have again increased our guidance for revenue and adjusted EPS. We expect now 2015 revenue to be between $2.645 billion and $2.67 billion, up from our previous guidance of which was $2.585 billion to $2.635 billion and reflects constant currency organic revenue growth of 11% to 12% for the year. This strong revenue growth is partially offset again by approximately 3% negative FX impact. And as before, this is all organic revenue growth. 2015 adjusted EPS is now expected to be in the range of $3 -- $4.38 to $4.42 a share, also up from our previous guidance, and this reflects 13% of 14% EPS growth for the year. On a constant currency basis, excluding $0.10 per share negative impact of FX at current rates, this reflects 15% to 16% growth for the year when compared to 1% [ph] growth in 2011. 
In summary, we're also more intently focused now on strategic inorganic growth as we've developed a more robust pipeline of potential opportunities now that we have fully integrated the TDX into our operations. So as I've talked to you in the past, the attempt was to be more focused on -- as we exited 2015 and into 2016, we're ready to do just that. 
So that's all the prepared comments. So operator, if you could please open up for Q&A for John and I, that would be great.

Third, as I've alluded to my comments, almost every -- in fact, I think every non-mortgage vertical is growing strong, strong double digits. So that's pretty preemployment, that's collection, that's automotive, that's card, I can go on and on and on, extremely strong. And then as you mentioned, Workforce Analytics, we continue to have customers there. I said 10 million consumers are now being -- employees are now being monitored and 62 clients alone in the month of June. So it is broad-based, the performance of growth that you could hope for in EWS is just spectacular.

componenttext: Great question. It's still early, and we gave you a number early in the year. It's ahead of that rate at this juncture, but we saw 6 months in the year, so it's hard to say where they go through full year at this time. It's been very successful. We like the model. And as we talk to you in the past, we look at that B to C business through our consumer direct-to-consumer as unified strategy. So in this particular case, we have our PSol unit and USIS working together strategically to make sure this makes sense now not just short term but long term. And yes, there's nothing to prevent us from looking at taking the success of out Credit Karmain and either doing ourselves directly or doing with other indirect players.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess one of the things that jump up to me, Rick, is even get into Q3 as you start anniversary-ing the mortgage you're still guiding to 10% to 12% constant currency growth. And as you talk about the business, it sounds like almost every business unit is
componenttext: I guess one of the things that jump up to me, Rick, is even get into Q3 as you start anniversary-ing the mortgage you're still guiding to 10% to 12% constant currency growth. And as you talk about the business, it sounds like almost every business unit is or above the long-term guidance ranges. So is there anything that is unsustainable on the growth rate? Or said another way, when you're under sweet spot of the consumer credit cycle in some of the larger developed markets, can you sustainably grow above the longer-term targets?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's obviously something we'll develop over time, something we keep a close eye on, Jeff, on the horizon we're looking at specific to the third quarter guidance maybe the second half guidance. You're right, it's not just every business unit, it's the su
componenttext: That's obviously something we'll develop over time, something we keep a close eye on, Jeff, on the horizon we're looking at specific to the third quarter guidance maybe the second half guidance. You're right, it's not just every business unit, it's the sub-business units within those business units and the sub-sub. So that could be the auto vertical within International but also the auto vertical within all the countries in International performing extremely well. It's very, very broad-based, and the execution are extremely high level. Let me use your question to respond something I briefly alluded to in my comments, which is the nuances of mortgage and how mortgage impacts our thinking for the balance of the year and next year. And you guys know this as well as we do. The world is going -- of the U.S. market is going from a heavily refinancing distribution and now back to more than normal distribution, which is heavily skewed towards purchases and less and less towards refinancing. And while the overall mortgage market will soften, I think it clearly is going to soften in second half of this year versus the first half of 2015 will be less than 2,000 or modestly up from 2015. The nuance is positive for us is that when you go from the refinancing market to a home purchase market, it's actually a benefit. In many cases, individual bank policies may not require them to pull give you a verification income. When do a purchase, they pull a VOI. Secondly, when you go to a refinancing -- from refinancing to purchase, you're going to pull, as we told you in the past, far more credit files. Your broker may pull a credit file using the consumers shop to 4 different banks, 5 different banks, they start pulling the file. In refinancing, you don't do that. They may pull 1 file. So even though the mortgage market growth rates will slow as we go forward, including third quarter, we think there's some hidden gem there for us as we rebalance the purchase marketing.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good question. I think there's no single answer. I think generically, in the U.S., I think as I said in my comments, we were expecting improved economic environment. I talk about sweet spot of consumer credit as you exit this year and going to 2016. It's
componenttext: Good question. I think there's no single answer. I think generically, in the U.S., I think as I said in my comments, we were expecting improved economic environment. I talk about sweet spot of consumer credit as you exit this year and going to 2016. It's not robust yet in the U.S. It's improving. But the nuance and difference that would be the automotive obviously very strong, and we benefited from that. We also benefit -- we're growing at rate, multiples of the automotive growth rates, as you know, Shlomo, through our connector strategy with our partners and new product introduction, card with prescreen pickup, which is encouraging. And that should lead to more card revenue going forward. Insurance is strong. Retail banking is strong. So it's fairly broad-based. But the heart of your question is, other than automotive, the majority of the USIS growth that we're experiencing is not economic. Some of it is economic -- driven by the mortgage, driven by New product innovations, more spend with our customers, D360 things like that versus the market itself.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015

componenttext: And I think the rising tide will lift all boats eventually. But yes, we've been at D360 for I think it was in 2007, so 8 years. And all the things we've done by leveraging D360 and then building Cambrian, building NPI, it's those things, by and large, that are driving more of our core organic growth in the U.S. and the economic environment.

componenttext: Okay. Great. And then just turning to International. Clearly, top line growth in the ability to drive the top line is the key. Can you talk about the things that impacted the margin that are really longer-term efforts that you're making towards driving that top line?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, absolutely. As we talked about before, it's 2 big things we're doing. And what the beauty is, Shlomo, before I give you the 2 things we're doing is John and I have the luxury to invest in areas where we need to invest, and PSol is one of the investin
componenttext: Yes, absolutely. As we talked about before, it's 2 big things we're doing. And what the beauty is, Shlomo, before I give you the 2 things we're doing is John and I have the luxury to invest in areas where we need to invest, and PSol is one of the investing now for a couple of years, as an example. We told you, we'll accelerate the growth there from our competitors, but the margin will come down 25% to 30%. We also told you we're going to invest in International for long-term growth and profitability. We can do those things and still give you -- we told we're going to do was 25 to 50 basis points corporate margin expansion, we've done that. And I think margins were up 120 basis points in the first quarter and 50 basis points in the second quarter. Specific your question, though, there are 2 things we're investing in International, which I firmly believe benefit us long term. One is the government contract we've talked about in the U.K. That is a large complicated investment that we've had to make the required resources from around the globe stand up this environment to be ready to go live end of the third quarter, early fourth quarter. And I think we've talked about now as a group for a few quarters. So that's one. The other has been with our ability now to standardize platforms, we're now going to regional standards in International. And there's a cost associated with moving from replicating processes in every country to regionalizing those processes in fewer countries. So there's an investment required to get -- those are the 2 things we're investing now as well as NPI, but we always do that and will bode well long term nn create some headwinds in margin in the short term.

componenttext: And just near term, what you're seeing in the first half of this year is we just have a revenue mix change, right? We talked about Canada being a little weaker, a lot of it because of FX. There's an FX impact. But also Canada is a very high-margin country for us, similar to USIS. So when Canada is weaker, it affects our international margins.

componenttext: Very sustainable. Dennis has done hell of a job taking a very good business and bringing it to a new level. And we told you -- we talked about this for quite some time, we have a path to get the record up to 300 million. And every time you had a record, you get multiple bites of the Apple. It becomes more valuable for more verticals. You have revenue added just incrementally for that record being added. So that's one. Two, Workforce Analytics are at very early stages. IRS piece of that Workforce Analytics goes live in February of 2016. So we haven't even experienced that revenue growth yet. The non-verification piece of EWS, we get a great leader and they're doing a great job of thinking that, that business no longer is protecting The Work Number but innovating, investing in efficiency for our customers and making customer experience better, taking that business from a virtually no growth to nicely growing business. So as I look, Gary, at the portfolio assets we have, told our investors time and time again, I think we're all really well-positioned for the long, multiyear -- long-term, multiyear growth. We got I think the most significant growth opportunities over a multiyear period of time is, in fact, EWS.

I intentionally described it in our larger developed markets, so U.K., Canada and U.S. and underline to underscore particularly the U.S. What you got is the emergence of obviously higher employment rates or unemployment rates starting to see wage growth, starting to see home price growth, continued home price growth. Consumer confidence is growing. The banks are stronger now than they have ever been, so their ability to lend for those that want to borrow is as strong now -- is becoming strong now as it's been since maybe the 2005, '06, '07 time frame. So that's why I'm saying. I feel like in those countries specifically, we're moving into the what I view is a sweet spot for consumer credit and obviously that benefits us.

componenttext: Emphatically, yes. And it's not just NPI 2.0. There's something I think we introduced to you and alluded to today. And that's why we introduced EGI maybe 3 or 4 years ago is we always had challenges to finding different ways to innovate for customers.

componenttextpreview: I'm looking at it. It's starting to come back. We're not heavily focused in the affinity market as others are. We're heavily focused in the indirect market, and I think I alluded to in my earnings notes that that's growing strong double digit just for us.
componenttext: I'm looking at it. It's starting to come back. We're not heavily focused in the affinity market as others are. We're heavily focused in the indirect market, and I think I alluded to in my earnings notes that that's growing strong double digit just for us. We're not a heavy player in the affinity market.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, then, back in April, you announced the the new version of the FICO score that use the NCTUE data to help generate a FICO score for consumers that didn't have sufficient data in their credit files to do a traditional FICO score. So how is that p
componenttext: Yes. Well, then, back in April, you announced the the new version of the FICO score that use the NCTUE data to help generate a FICO score for consumers that didn't have sufficient data in their credit files to do a traditional FICO score. So how is that pilot going and does it have a chance to become a meaningful contributor to revenue for you someday?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think so. It's early days, but I think anytime we can help our customers. We have banks or telcos get transparency and better insights into the under-banked. They win, the under-banked win and we win. I alluded to the fact that one of the Latin American
componenttext: I think so. It's early days, but I think anytime we can help our customers. We have banks or telcos get transparency and better insights into the under-banked. They win, the under-banked win and we win. I alluded to the fact that one of the Latin American companies were building capabilities within an exchange had transparency in that exact segment. It has nothing to do with the FICO score that you're talking about. That's a utility database, but it's the same concept, how do you get transparency to the under-banked. And I think if we do that smartly and a FICO scores are willing to do that, again that's a win-win-win.

componenttext: No, I did not. I talked to someone who asked the question, David, I can't recall who it was, about Work Number. And I talked about long-term growth and we clearly have the path of strategy our total record goes to 300 million. David, maybe 1 or 2 years ago, I intentionally talked less about the active. That's growing nicely, by the way. It's growing very nicely and our path is what we want to get. But I'm talking more about this path of 300 million records because there was a missed number that I feel maybe 8 years ago with EWS in that -- there's more value, value in active versus total. We do a lot of value from the historical records as well. So in an attempt to make sure everyone understood that, we're really talking about getting the total database up to 300 million. We're on our way.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good question. Thank you for at asking that. Medium term, I know your question is long term, medium term, how that means, I'm bearish in Brazil. Political, economically, it's in a down cycle, and I'm not sure that's another 2 years, 3 years, but it's toug
componenttext: Good question. Thank you for at asking that. Medium term, I know your question is long term, medium term, how that means, I'm bearish in Brazil. Political, economically, it's in a down cycle, and I'm not sure that's another 2 years, 3 years, but it's tough. Secondly, there's -- I think everyone knows, there's a law passed couple of years ago to include positive data, which we thought was a positive. No pun intended there. There is a cloud over that possibility. It's likely or possible the the positive bureau is, in fact, controlled and built by the banks, much like the -- if you remember of old any negative data was built. So I'm not sure strategically what that does to the Brazilian market long term. So right now, I've always said before, I get aggressive and going to step up our ownership in Brazil. I don't really understand what the economy is going to do and how long it's been down in the environment and where just the positive bureau go. And I think we have clarity on the latter, positive probably in the next 12 months, and we'll make a decision at that point in time. In the meantime, there are good partners. TMG is a good partner. This is a good partner. We continue to work with them to make sure that they're successful as possible.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015

componenttext: We'll take our next question from Brett Huff from Stephens, Inc.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: You talked a little bit about EGI, and I think it's the first time you called out maybe 1 or 2 points of growth from that and I was -- it seems like that was more than in my mind that, that might be contributing. And I guess I have a 2-part question. One
componenttext: You talked a little bit about EGI, and I think it's the first time you called out maybe 1 or 2 points of growth from that and I was -- it seems like that was more than in my mind that, that might be contributing. And I guess I have a 2-part question. One is, when you're sort of duking it out for wallet share with the other bureaus and the other relevant players, what's helping you win in that relationship? Is it just the long-term relationship? Is it the incremental unique data sets you have, et cetera? And then number two, what take that to the next level? Is it just execution and going through just systematically each of your top 50 customers or whatever it is? Or is there another gear in EGI that helps you even accelerate from 1 to 2 points?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Brett. I'd say, well, we've got good competitors and I respect our competitors. they do a good job in marketplace and or get experience or local competitors or local countries. So you can't underestimate the power of having good people, and we've
componenttext: Thanks, Brett. I'd say, well, we've got good competitors and I respect our competitors. they do a good job in marketplace and or get experience or local competitors or local countries. So you can't underestimate the power of having good people, and we've blessed have some really good, talented and committed people. And beyond that, I'd say there's no doubt that innovation, be it through EGI or through NPI leverage our unique data assets has been a huge differentiator over the years. And I tell people that the growth in that area of innovation isn't always or even largely share gain. It is in some cases, clearly, Brett, but it is solving problems that no one else can solve. So if they suspect $100 in ecosystem. If you're now spending $110, we get the incremental $10 spend. That's really we're the great leverage is. And then the other thing is where am I going to go -- yes, you can't others will be neighborhood long term for us. So beyond that, how you sustain that, yes, I think it's sustainable midterm and long term. As I mentioned with someone else's question earlier, we are continuing to reinvent ourselves, remain contemporary. I think we're always going to say, what has been excessive we need that adds value to our customers that our competition or the marketplace is not adding today. So in our strategic planning process, we always think about what is next, and we said that we not alluded to here, but that's something we think about.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015

componenttext: Oh, clearly, multiyear. I mean, people get -- see, I can promise you this, the majority of companies we talk to CEOs, we talk to the Chief HR officers, they're thinking about this today. And they're looking to us or someone else in the marketplace to solve those problems, they're trying their own homegrown solutions and get their compliance and get done. So [indiscernible] start to melt, their need for solutions go up and the urgency for solutions go up. Secondly, I alluded, Gary, in my comments that the IRS piece of the compliance goes live February of next year, so we haven't even monetized that yet to its fullest extent. So I think if it's a baseball analogy, the Workforce Analytics potential is in a very early innings of its growth.

Good day, and welcome to the second quarter 2015 earnings call. Today's conference is being recorded. 
At this time, I'd like to turn the conference over to Jeff Dodge. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, and good morning. Welcome to today's conference call. I'm Jeff Dodge, Investor Relations, and with me today are Rick Smith, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and John Gamble, Chief Financial Officer. Today's call is being recorded. An archiv
componenttext:
Thanks, and good morning. Welcome to today's conference call. I'm Jeff Dodge, Investor Relations, and with me today are Rick Smith, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and John Gamble, Chief Financial Officer. 
Today's call is being recorded. An archive of the recording will be available later today in the Investor Relations section of in the About Equifax tab of our website at www.equifax.com. During this call, we'll be making certain forward-looking statements to help you understand Equifax and its business environment. These statements involve a number of risks, uncertainties and other factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from our expectations. Certain risk factors inherent in our business are set forth in our filings with the SEC, including our 2014 Form 10-K and subsequent filings. 
We will be referring to certain non-GAAP financial measures, including adjusted EPS attributable to Equifax that will be adjusted for certain items, which affect the comparability of the underlying operational performance. Adjusted EPS attributable to Equifax excludes acquisition-related amortization expense and the associated tax effects, an impairment charge related to our cost method investment in BVS and an income tax benefit generated from a state tax law change. These measures are detailed in our non-GAAP reconciliation tables included with our earnings release and also posted on our website. Also, please refer to our various investor presentations, which are posted in the Investor Relations section of our website, www.investor.equifax.com, for further details. 
Now I'd like to turn it over to Rick.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jeff. Good morning, everyone. Thanks, as always, for joining us this morning. By now you've seen the results and I think you'd agree our company continues to benefit from our unique and very diversified business model, also benefits from our high
componenttext:
Thanks, Jeff. Good morning, everyone. Thanks, as always, for joining us this morning. By now you've seen the results and I think you'd agree our company continues to benefit from our unique and very diversified business model, also benefits from our high level of execution across all the BUs in the centers of excellences, and we continue to reap benefits from the new product innovation that we've launched back in 2006. For the quarter, both revenue and adjusted EPS exceeded the upper end of our guidance range for all 4 business units, and they delivered revenue growth ahead of our expectations. This reflected both our continued execution of new products and market expansions as well as a stronger-than-expected U.S. mortgage market. 
Total revenue for the quarter was $678 million, up 10% on a reported basis and up 14% on a local currency basis from the second quarter of 2014. In the quarter, FX created a $19 million year-on-year headwind, up from the headwind we experienced in the first quarter of $17 million. Operating margin for the quarter was 27.8%, up from 27.3% in the second quarter of 2014. Adjusted EPS was $1.15, up 20% from $0.96 a share last year and significantly above the upper end of our guidance range. As always [indiscernible] before John gives us some financial details, I'll go through some of the business unit highlights as well as some of the corporate highlights, and I'll go into the details of the financials with John. 
The power of our Decision 360 initiative, which you, by now, are very well aware of, combined with our enterprise selling strategy and our mortgage market success enabled USIS to once again deliver very strong, broad-based 12% growth. Our recently launched data and analytics environment, which we've introduced to you and we call it Cambrian, has positioned us to develop and deliver new D360 products at speed that once took weeks, now take us minutes. This is something you'll recall we've talked about now for probably 2 years, and that is now fully in production in the U.S. and making a big difference. 
The primary goal of Cambrian is to source and integrate structured and unstructured data from any industry anywhere in the world and proactively deliver actual [ph] insights valued by our customers. What's particularly compelling is that we can now create transformational solutions like combining traditional, trusted data with other Big Data sources and cutting-edge analytical capabilities with greater ease and speed. Cambrian will help us discover new data assets for our research and/or partnerships that will further broaden and deepen our portfolio of data assets and fuel new product innovation. 
Specially for Cambrian, the environment is focused on our U.S.-based data assets and market opportunities. However, as we've talked in the past, we'll be developing significant domain expertise that will enable us to expand into our International geographies over the next 6 to 12 months. 
Moving on. And in the auto vertical in the U.S., we recently launched the first of 3 products in the power lead suite, which leverages our data assets to help auto dealers be more effective in their marketing activities in leveraging third-party service providers or connectors, as we call them. We help dealers leverage their website performance by turning anonymous borrowers into known high-quality leads. Consumers are now more empowered by getting their credit score online after being authenticated with our eIDverifier services, and all this information is with the consumer authorization it's then shared with the dealers. 
Our partnership with Credit Karma, I think we've talked to you about that back in the very end of 2013, nearly 2014. That continues to be -- is that right? '14, '15, yes, very end of '14, sorry about that. That continues to be a very important revenue contributor to USIS and is off to a great start this year. We now expect the revenue in relationship with Credit Karma for 2015 to exceed our original expectations. 
Staying in the USIS, in the utility sector, we launched our -- the first of our 4 market-specific insight tools, leveraging third-party data alongside our credit information in our telco and utility database. These insights will help utilities optimize their deposit strategies to better manage and control portfolio loss rates. 
Our Commercial Solutions business within USIS, the product offerings and business unit had a very strong performance in the quarter, with both accelerating revenue growth and improved operating margins when compared to the first quarter of the year. Mortgage origination activity exceeded our expectations for the quarter and driven by our strong market position, contributed nicely to USIS' growth and margin expansion. Our fraud and property valuation product offerings continue to deliver very strong double-digit growth in the mortgage market as well. We'll talk on these in the Q&A, more about mortgage and where we think that's headed. 
Finally, our partnership with Jumio, which we talked to you about in the past, has secured first mobile commerce authentication service with a major telco. The application includes validation of an end-user's photo ID, along with facial biometrics, a first for us. While we expect the mortgage growth to decelerate for the remainder of the year, we expect USIS to end 2015 with double-digit organic revenue growth and operating margins comfortably exceeding 40%. 
So on to International. They continue to make very good progress on their critical strategic growth initiatives, including the integration of TDX, implementation of the U.K. government contract and continue to drive innovation through new products around the globe. Revenue in International's 3 largest verticals, which are the financial institutions, telcos and SMEs, grew 13% for the quarter. The decisioning platforms, analytic services and debt management revenue grew 17% for the quarter. 
TDX delivered another quarter of 20%-plus revenue growth, a trend we expect to continue as we move into the third quarter. Also, we are in the process of entering the Canadian and Brazilian markets with TDX products and services. We're also meeting all of our operational readiness commitments within TDX over the U.K. contract that we've talked about in the past. 
Equifax data has been integrated into the TDX workflow. We're developing the consumer insights and appropriate collection strategies. The IT infrastructure build has been completed and security penetration testing is largely completed. 20 debt collection agency contracts have been signed after bidding with the U.K. government. And as we mentioned in the past, we expect this to be operational late fourth quarter, early fourth quarter, a modest revenue this year and ramping up nicely in 2016. 
Moving on Latin America. We've identified opportunities to set up exchanges just like we do in the U.S., where critical data assets are not currently available. We've already received regulatory approval in one country and we'll be finalizing our plans by the end of the year. As you know, the exchanges have been very successful in the U.S. with good margins and good competitive differentiation, helping our customers in ways we couldn't help before. We're really excited about what this might bring us in this 1 country, if it's successful there, we'll bring it across other Latin American countries. 
In Canada, we launched a 6-month pilot for e-commerce site to provide online delivery for our business and consumer credit product offerings. This distribution channel will be very attractive to our SME customers while also addressing a growing market demand in other verticals and potentially other geographies. 
And we recently signed a global agreement with a large international telecom to create new analytical insights using telecom usage data. Ultimately, the analytical insights will be sold to financial institutions, retailers and other customers in our served markets to facilitate decisioning on consumers who have limited or no credit information. This partnership is significant for Equifax as a new source of rich data for consumers in Latin America, which is typically a negative-data-only geography. We're starting with the risk scores that are developed from our telecom data to address the pain point of FIN file and no hit at the point of acquisition. Over time, we'll expand this beyond account acquisition to other decisioning needs. 
For the full year, we expect the International revenue growth to be solidly in the upper end of their long-term growth range, which is 7% to 10% while we continue to grow -- invest in their long-term growth initiatives. On the Workforce Solutions, they again delivered an outstanding broad-based 23% revenue growth and a operating margin of 38.3%, and they're doing a great job of executing with precision on their strategic objectives. Revenue from all of our Affordable Care Act initiatives continue to accelerate nicely. And with the recent Supreme Court decision, we anticipate continued strong demand for our product offerings in this area. 
In our ACA platform solution, which enables companies to know the extent of their compliance with the Affordable Care Act, we continue to benefit from very strong interest. We now have contracts with numerous employers who, in aggregate, now have 10 million employees on their payroll. In June alone, we signed 62 new customer contracts. We're uniquely positioned to add value in the healthcare vertical, and we will be making important investments to drive further long-term revenue growth and market penetration. 
Strong growth in Verification Services was driven by continuing to add records, new records to The Work Number database, also double-digit growth in mortgage originations and continued penetration of non-mortgage market verticals. In the quarter, our non-mortgage market verification revenue grew 21%, virtually every vertical growing strong double digit for the quarter, outstanding performance. 
Growth in mortgage-related revenues decelerated in the second quarter, a trend that will continue for the remainder of the year. However, Workforce Solutions' success on many of their strategic initiatives should continue to drive very attractive revenue growth. For the full year, we now expect revenue growth to be in the upper teens with margin expansion over 2014 of at least 400 basis points to approximately 37%. 
On the PSOL, the PSOL's growth exceeded our expectation, driven by double-digit growth in our indirect channels and our International segments in addition to winning 2 bridge contracts. Revenue growth for our direct-to-consumer activities in the U.S. continues to be driven by higher average revenue per subscriber and lower churn. They've done a great job on both ARPU in churn. PSOL is making good progress on their transformation efforts, and we expect full year organic revenue growth to be at the upper end of a long-term range of 4% to 6% and operating margins for the full year solidly in the range of 25% to 30%. 
So again, before I go to John with the financial details, let me give you some highlights at the corporate level quickly, some things we've talked about in the past that are very critical to our sustained organic growth. You've heard me talk about NPI 2.0 and you heard me talk about EGI, that's critically important growth initiatives. In NPI 2.0, we developed detailed metrics to better manage our pipeline of opportunities, more effectively allocate our resources and track our success on product launches and to minimize time to revenue. Midway to the year, we are now 10% overall revenue target, so the team is doing a great job of executing again in NPI. 
Our enterprise growth initiatives, we call it EGI, where we're focused on larger, more complex projects and frequently engage multiple parts of the organization. We also have much bigger impact on the revenue growth. EGI is delivering, again, 1 to 2 points of revenue growth annually for us. 
In global operations, that COE continues to make important contributions to our bottom line. Within the operations COE, you've heard us talk about LEAN initiatives, which traditionally have been used internally. We've talked a lot about that. However, with the increased level of competition and regulatory requirements in many of our industry verticals, there are many new opportunities for incremental revenue growth, and we leveraged LEAN within our customers' operations. Our global LEAN team is now -- are currently engaged with over 20 great customers, helping to drive operational improvements that are critical to their success while adding yet another element of differentiation for our business in the marketplace. So our customers have become stronger, more efficient and it helps us differentiate versus competition and secure incremental revenue. 
On to our fraud and identity management business. They're presently broadening to incorporate biometrics in mobile device resolution. We have partnerships. We're also looking -- taking a more successful product and launching them in other geographies. It's a practice we've done in other parts of the business. Now we're intentionally taking Fraud and ID products in all parts of the world to other geographies where it makes sense. 
In summary, the business is off to a solid start this year, with high levels of execution across many of our strategic initiatives. And we're well down the path of changing Equifax from a credit bureau into a truly diversified Information Solutions company. Our domain expertise in analytics and technology enabled us to increasingly deliver powerful insights to our customers and enhance their decision-making. All of our business units continue to work hard to deliver on their commitments to the company, our customers, employees and shareholders. And as we move into the second half of 2015 and start to look at 2016, I strongly believe the prospects for consumer credit in the developed markets, which we operate, especially the U.S., look very good. The dynamics are shaping up as a sweet spot now for consumer credit growth. 
And with that, let me turn it over to John with the financials. John?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rick, and good morning, everyone. As before, I'll be referring to the financial results from continuing operations generally presented on a GAAP basis. During the quarter, we recorded an impairment charge of $14.8 million or $9.8 million after-tax
componenttext:
Thanks, Rick, and good morning, everyone. As before, I'll be referring to the financial results from continuing operations generally presented on a GAAP basis. During the quarter, we recorded an impairment charge of $14.8 million or $9.8 million after-tax related to our cost method investment in BBS. The impairment is, in general, a result of the weakened economic situation in Brazil. We also recorded an $8.6 million after-tax gain due to a state income tax benefit resulting from a state tax law change enacted during the quarter. The net of these 2 unusual items was negative $0.01 per share. Consistent with our past practice for treating unusual or infrequent items, we've excluded these items from our adjusted EPS in order to provide investors with a more consistent period-to-period operating comparison. 
Now let me turn to the business units' financial performance for the second quarter. U.S. Information Solutions revenue was $316 million, up 12% when compared to the second quarter of '14. Online Information Solutions revenue was $233 million, up 13% when compared to the year-ago period. Mortgage Solutions revenue was $33 million, up 20% compared to Q2 of 2014. This compares favorably to the Mortgage Bankers Application Index, which was up 16% in the second quarter. Financial Marketing Services revenue was $50 million, up 4% when compared to the year-ago quarter. And the operating margin for U.S. Information Solutions was 42.1%, up from 39.5% in the second quarter of 2014. International revenue was $148 million, down 1% on a reported basis but up 11% on a local currency basis. 
By region, Europe's revenue was $63 million, down 1% in U.S. dollars but up 12% in local currency. Latin America's revenue was $51 million, up 6% in U.S. dollars and 18% in local currency. Canada revenue was $35 million, down 10% in U.S. dollars but up 2% in local currency. For the second quarter, International's operating margin was 19.9%, down from 21.9% in the second quarter of 2014. Although the operating margin fell short of our expectations, we have a number of very exciting growth opportunities Rick has discussed that were an incremental investment and management focus. Workforce Solutions revenue was $146 million for the quarter, up 23% when compared to the second quarter of '14. Verification Services, with revenue of $94 million, was up 30% when compared to the same quarter of last year. Employer Services revenue was $52 million, up 11% compared to last year. Growth was aided by our ACA analytical solutions and the further progress with Compliance Center. 
The Workforce Solutions operating margin was 38.3% compared to 33.9% in Q2 of '14. Personal Solutions revenue was $68 million, up 7% on a reported basis and up 8% on a local currency basis. For the second quarter, operating margin was 27.6% compared to 30.9% in Q2 of 2014. This margin is consistent with our longer-term expectations for this business as we primarily -- driven by increased marketing expense during the quarter. 
In the second quarter, general corporate expense at $48.5 million was slightly over the guidance we gave last year. The increase versus our guidance, and from the $36.6 million in 2Q of 2014, was principally due to increased incentive compensation expense due to our very strong performance in 2015. We also had increased salaries and benefits and other investment expense primarily related to our key strategic initiatives. 
Looking at the third and fourth quarter, we expect general corporate expense to be approximately $45 million for the quarter, consistent with 2014 levels. Operating margin at 27.8% was very strong. Operating cash flow was $187 million in the quarter. We continued our aggressive stock buyback activity, repurchasing 0.9 million shares for $92 million and paying $34 million in dividends to our shareholders. 
With that, I'll turn it back to Rick.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. Consistent with our guidance last quarter, we expect continued favorable economic conditions in the U.S., span the majority of our non-mortgage verticals. I'll talk about mortgage in a second. International, we continue to expect uneven econ
componenttext:
Thanks, John. Consistent with our guidance last quarter, we expect continued favorable economic conditions in the U.S., span the majority of our non-mortgage verticals. I'll talk about mortgage in a second. International, we continue to expect uneven economic conditions across Europe and Latin America. And our view of the U.S. mortgage market in the second half of 2015 is roughly consistent with our prior guidance as we expect U.S. mortgage market originations to be up slightly in the second half of 2015 versus the same period in 2014. And we are, however, increasing our full year view for 2015 mortgage originations to be up somewhere between 11% and 13% versus 2014. The U.S. mortgage market was stronger than our expectations in the first half of the year, with originations up approximately 20% versus last year. And again, we'll talk about the nuances and the impact of moving from a refinancing mortgage market to a purchase market, which we're in the process of doing, the benefits that has for our company. 
For the third quarter, we expect revenue -- organic revenue growth to be -- organic revenue to be between $655 million and $670 million, reflecting constant currency organic growth between 10% and 12%, partially offset by about 3% FX headwind. Adjusted EPS is expected to be between $1.08 and $1.11 a share, which is up 7% to 10% excluding $0.03 per share of negative impact from FX. This reflects constant currency organic EPS growth of 10% to 15%. We also expect operating margin to be in the range of 27% to 27.5% for the quarter. For the full year, we have again increased our guidance for revenue and adjusted EPS. We expect now 2015 revenue to be between $2.645 billion and $2.67 billion, up from our previous guidance which was $2.585 billion to $2.635 billion and reflects constant currency organic revenue growth of 11% to 12% for the year. 
This strong revenue growth is partially offset again by approximately 3% negative FX impact. And as before, this is all organic revenue growth. 2015 adjusted EPS is now expected to be in the range of $3 -- $4.38 to $4.42 a share, also up from our previous guidance, and this reflects 13% to 14% EPS growth for the year. On a constant currency basis, excluding $0.10 per share negative impact of FX at current rates, this reflects 15% to 16% growth for the year when compared to 11% growth in 2011. 
In summary, we're also more intently focused now on strategic inorganic growth as we've developed a more robust pipeline of potential opportunities now that we have fully integrated TDX into our operations. So as I've talked to you in the past, the intent was to be more focused on that as we exit 2015 and into 2016. We're ready to do just that. 
So that's all the prepared comments. So operator, if you could please open up for Q&A for John and I, that would be great.

So that's preemployment, that's collections, that's automotive, that's card, I can go on and on and on, extremely strong. And then as you mentioned, the Workforce Analytics, we continue to have customers there. I said 10 million consumers are now being -- employees are now being monitored and 62 clients alone in the month of June. So it is as broad-based a performance of growth as you could hope for in EWS, just spectacular.

componenttext: Great question. It's still early so -- and we gave you a number early in the year. It's ahead of that rate at this juncture but we still have 6 months in the year to go, so it's hard to say where they'd through a full year at this time. It's been very successful. We like the model. And as we talked to you in the past, we look at that deed to see, be it through a business, through a consumer or direct-to-consumer, as 1 unified strategy. So in this particular case, we have our PSOL unit and USIS working together strategically to make sure this makes sense, not just short term but long term. And yes, there's nothing to prevent us from looking at taking the success with Credit Karma and either doing it ourselves directly or doing with other indirect players.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess one of the things that jumped up to me, Rick, is even getting out to Q3 as you start anniversary-ing the mortgage weakness still guiding to 10% to 12% constant currency growth. And as you talk about the business, it sounds like almost every busine
componenttext: I guess one of the things that jumped up to me, Rick, is even getting out to Q3 as you start anniversary-ing the mortgage weakness still guiding to 10% to 12% constant currency growth. And as you talk about the business, it sounds like almost every business unit is at or above the long-term guidance ranges. So is there anything that is unsustainable on the growth rate? Or said another way, when you're in a sweet spot of the consumer credit cycle in some of the larger developed markets, can you sustainably grow above the longer-term targets?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's obviously something we'll develop over time, something we keep a close eye on, Jeff. It depends on the horizon you're looking at specific to the third quarter guidance, maybe the second half guidance. You're right, it's not just every business unit
componenttext: That's obviously something we'll develop over time, something we keep a close eye on, Jeff. It depends on the horizon you're looking at specific to the third quarter guidance, maybe the second half guidance. You're right, it's not just every business unit, it's the sub-business units within those business units and the sub-sub. So that could be the auto vertical within International but also the auto vertical within all the countries in International performing extremely well. It's very, very broad-based, and their execution is at extremely high level. Let me use your question to respond to something I briefly alluded to in my comments, which is the nuances of mortgage and how mortgage impacts our thinking for the balance of the year and next year. And you guys know this as well as we do. The world is going -- the U.S. market is going from a heavily refinancing distribution to now back to more the normal distribution, which is heavily skewed towards purchases and less and less towards refinancing. And while the overall mortgage market will soften, I think it clearly is going to soften in second half of this year versus the first half 2015 will be less than 2,000 or maybe modestly up from 2015. The nuance that's positive for us is that when you go from a refinancing market to a home purchase market, it's actually a benefit. In many cases, individual bank policies may not require them to pull a VOE/VOI verification income. When you do a purchase, they pull a VOE/VOI. Secondly, when you go to a refinancing -- from refinancing to purchase, you're going to pull, as we told you in the past, far more credit files. Your broker may pull a credit file. Usually, a consumer may shop to 4 different banks, 5 different banks, each time pulling a file. In refinancing, you don't do that. They may pull 1 file. So even though the mortgage market growth rates will slow as we go forward, including third quarter, we think there's some hidden gems in there for us as you rebalance to a purchase marketing.

Could you talk about it's getting better? And how much more just some of the initiatives that you've been very aggressive about for, like, besides the credit card but also things like fraud initiatives, ID identification and other things out there? So I guess, how much is market versus how much is you guys just trying to anticipate where the best places are to be?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good question. I think there's no single answer. I think generically, in the U.S., I think I said this in some of my comments, we were expecting improved economic environment. I'm talking about moving to a sweet spot of consumer credit as you exit this ye
componenttext: Good question. I think there's no single answer. I think generically, in the U.S., I think I said this in some of my comments, we were expecting improved economic environment. I'm talking about moving to a sweet spot of consumer credit as you exit this year and going to 2016. It's not robust yet in the U.S. It's improving. The nuance and difference there would be the automotive, obviously very strong. And we benefited from that but we also benefit -- we're growing at rates, multiples of the automotive growth rates, as you know, Shlomo, through our connector strategy with our partners and new product introduction, card using prescreen pick-up, which is encouraging. And that should lead to more card revenue going forward. Insurance is strong. Retail banking is strong. So it's fairly broad-based. But the heart of your question is, other than automotive, the majority of the USIS growth that we're experiencing is not economic -- some of it is economically driven, the mortgage driven by New product innovation, more spend with our customers, leveraging D360 things like that versus the market itself.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015

componenttext: And I think the rising tide will lift all boats eventually but yes, we've been at D360, for God's sake, I think it's in 2007, so 8 years. And all the things we've done by leveraging D360 and then building Cambrian, building NPI, it's those things, by and large, that are driving more of our core organic growth in the U.S. and just the economic environment.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015

componenttext: Okay. Great. And then just turning to International. Clearly, top line growth and the ability to drive the top line is the key. Can you talk about the things that impacted the margin that are really longer-term efforts that you're making towards driving that top line?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, absolutely. It's consistent with what we talked about before, it's 2 big things we're doing. And what the beauty is, Shlomo, before I give you the 2 things we're doing is John and I have the luxury to invest in areas where we need to invest, and PSOL
componenttext: Yes, absolutely. It's consistent with what we talked about before, it's 2 big things we're doing. And what the beauty is, Shlomo, before I give you the 2 things we're doing is John and I have the luxury to invest in areas where we need to invest, and PSOL is one where we've been investing in now for a couple of years, as an example. We told you, we'll accelerate the growth there from our competitors but the margin will come down 25% to 30%. We also told you we're going to invest in International for long-term growth and profitability. We can do those things and still give you what we told you we're going to do which is a 25 to 50 basis points corporate margin expansion, we've done that. And I think margins were up 120 basis points in the first quarter and 50 basis points in the second quarter. Specific to your question, though, there are 2 things we're investing in, in International, which I firmly believe benefit us long term. One is the government contract we've talked about in the U.K. That is a large complicated investment that we've had to make, there's required resources from around the globe to stand up in this environment, to be ready to go live end of the third quarter, early fourth quarter. And I think we've talked about that now as a group for a few quarters. So that's one. The other has been with our ability now to standardize platforms, we're now going to regional standards in International. And there's a cost associated with moving from replicating processes in every country to regionalizing those processes in fewer countries. So there's an investment required to get those. Those are 2 things we're investing in now as well as NPI, but we always do that, and it will bode well long term, it creates some headwinds in margin short term.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: And just near term, to what you're seeing in the first half of this year is we just have a revenue mix change, right. We talked about Canada being a little weaker, a lot of it because of FX. There's an FX impact but also Canada is a very high-margin count
componenttext: And just near term, to what you're seeing in the first half of this year is we just have a revenue mix change, right. We talked about Canada being a little weaker, a lot of it because of FX. There's an FX impact but also Canada is a very high-margin country for us, similar to USIS. So when Canada is weaker, it affects our international margins.
