headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, and welcome to the Equifax Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Mr. Jeff Dodge. Please go ahead, sir.
componenttext: Good day, and welcome to the Equifax Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Mr. Jeff Dodge. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to today's conference call. I'm Jeff Dodge, Investor Relations, and with me today are Rick Smith, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and John Gamble, Chief Financial Officer.Today's call is being recorded.
componenttext:
Thanks, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to today's conference call. I'm Jeff Dodge, Investor Relations, and with me today are Rick Smith, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and John Gamble, Chief Financial Officer.
Today's call is being recorded. An archive of the recording will be available later today in the Investor Relations section in the About Equifax tab of our website at www.equifax.com.
During this call, we'll be making certain forward-looking statements to help you understand Equifax and its business environment. These statements involve a number of risks, uncertainties and other factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from our expectations. Certain risk factors inherent in our business are set forth in the filings with the SEC, including our 2014 Form 10-K and subsequent filings.
During this call, we will be referring to certain non-GAAP financial measures, including adjusted EPS attributable to Equifax and adjusted operating margin. They will be adjusted for certain items, which affect the comparability of the underlying operational performance.
For the third quarter of 2015, adjusted EPS attributable to Equifax excludes acquisition-related amortization expense, income from the settlement of certain escrow amounts and an accrual for certain legal claims. Adjusted operating margin excludes the accrual for certain legal claims.
In the fourth quarter of 2015 and 2016, adjusted EPS attributable to Equifax will also exclude due diligence transaction and integration costs related to the proposed acquisition of beta group.
These non-GAAP measures are detailed in our reconciliation tables included with our earnings release and also posted on our website. Also, please refer to our various investor presentations, which are posted in the Investors Relations section of our website for further details. Now I'd like to turn it over to Rick.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jeff. Good morning, everyone. As always, thank you for joining us this morning. Our strong first half momentum continued throughout the third quarter with very solid broad-based growth across most of our key market segments and countries. The mome
componenttext:
Thanks, Jeff. Good morning, everyone. As always, thank you for joining us this morning. Our strong first half momentum continued throughout the third quarter with very solid broad-based growth across most of our key market segments and countries. The momentum combined with good solid execution from the team and one of the deepest NPI pipelines we've had in over the past 10 years positions us well to move into the fourth quarter and in 2016. In my comments later this morning, I'll give you a further look at both the fourth quarter as we always do and 2016 as well.
The Equifax strategy is clearly resonating well with our customers, our core disciplines in New Product Innovation, LEAN, IT simplification, regulatory compliance and talent assessment are enabling stronger, more consistent execution across all of our initiatives. 
For the quarter, total revenue was up -- was $667 million, up 9% on a reported basis and up 12% on local currency basis in the third quarter of 2014 and at the high-end of our guidance. In the quarter Equifax had a $22 million year-over-year headwind, up from the second quarter headwind, which was $19 million. Adjusted operating margin was 27.2%, up nicely from 26.4% in the third quarter of 2014. Adjusted EPS was $1.14, up 13% from $1.01 last year last year and above the upper end of our guidance range that we provided back a few months ago.
As always, before John gives you the financial details, I'd like to briefly cover some key highlights for the third quarter. USIS has continued to power forward with 12% revenue growth and has a robust pipeline of opportunities, provide continued unique insights incorporating our multiple data assets. USIS delivered very solid broad-based growth in fraud and identity management solutions and commercial information. Both those businesses were up double digits versus 2014. Mortgage, direct-to-consumer and automotive were also very strong growth drivers for the quarter. And like the rest of the company, USIS is also benefiting from broad-based growth from NPI and our enterprise growth initiatives. A little more in NPI. There are 4 strategic levers to USIS efforts around New Product Innovation. They are: one, accelerating growth by linking those relevant data with expanded analytic capabilities; two, investing in vertical expertise to drive unparalleled insights; three, focusing on customer experience to optimize enterprise distribution; and four diversifying portfolio growth across the value chain. An interesting point is that almost 60% of the anticipated 3-year NPI revenue is focused on opportunities beyond the more traditional credit risk solutions that you know us for. 
Finally, this week, we announced a very exciting opportunity for Fannie Mae. Fannie Mae will begin incorporating Equifax credit data in addition to our verified employment and income on The Work Number database. The credit data provides new insights to lenders by expanding the credit information to aid the assessment of risk using updated analytical tools. Integrating The Work Number in the Fannie Mae system will make the process simple for consumers and reduce potential for fraud. We believe this will be a win-win for the consumers as well as the mortgage industry. There is work to be done on our side. And as a result, the revenue opportunities are expected to start sometime in the second or third quarter of next year. It will be a nice impact for both USIS and EWS. USIS is having an outstanding year in 2015. For the full year, we expect them to deliver double-digit organic revenue growth and operating margins comfortably exceeding 40%.
On to International, we delivered 14% local currency revenue growth leveraging the diversity in score customer verticals, New Product Innovation and unique platforms in fraud and debt management. As you know, we're now in the midst of starting up the U.K. government project we talked to you about now for a few quarters. We have provided Equifax consumer data to 1 government agency and have now received approximately GBP 265 million of past due receivables that we're now loading and analyzing and will soon move on to the collection agencies. As we've mentioned before, we expect nominal revenue growth in the fourth quarter this year, and we expect that to ramp up nicely in 2016. In summary, as it relates to that project, it is on track, on pace and meeting our expectations.
In addition, we are currently exceeding our expectations for the TDX business in places like Australia and relaunching that across many other countries throughout the remainder of 2015 and into 2016. In fact, purely making a point, as you think about the TDX platform, the debt management platform in 2016, it will then be dispersed through multiple countries as opposed to 1 central P&L that you're used to seeing or can see like we talked about in the U.K. Also, International new product innovation continues to be a very important contributor to International's long-term growth. Their focus is in area of analytical insights, enhanced decision solutions, new verticals and distribution channels and broadening their data assets. in International's 3 largest verticals: financial institutions, telcos and SMEs grew 17% in the third quarter versus a healthy 13% in the second quarter of 2015. platforms analytical services and our debt management revenue grew 19% in the quarter, accelerating from 17% in the second quarter of the year. In 2015, International successfully executed on the strategic initiatives, and very important business opportunities that will transform growth profile in the coming years. For the full year, we expect International revenue growth to be above the long-term range we talked about of 7% to 10% growth.
Workforce Solutions, which has had a solid performance, and I think you'll agree for the year, grew 13% revenue from its continued traction in its compliance solution products, broadening market penetration for verification in employment and income and some very sophisticated analytical insights. Employer interest in our workforce analytic solutions for the Affordable Care Act remains extremely strong. Our subscription-based ACA platform solution, which enables companies to better understand their level of compliance with the requirements of ACA, is one of our most successful NPI initiatives in my 10 years here. We're now expecting to have over 700 clients by the end of this year, and we're still getting a large number of interest -- inbound request, which bodes well for EWS in the employer services business within EWS for 2016 and beyond.
In addition to our core product offering focused on compliance, we're also exploring other opportunities that will enable us to address evolving market needs including fines and penalties under the act and any related appeals that follow. We believe this will further enhance our position in the marketplace and make us an even more valuable partner to all our customers. New Product Innovation continues to make meaningful contribution to revenue growth for EWS. We now expect to end the year with a vitality index of over 11% versus our target of 10% at the beginning of the year. Earlier this week, EWS was honored for the second year in a row with the Product of the Year award by the editors of Sherman Resource Magazine. Our I-9 anywhere product is a cutting-edge service that enables organizations to streamline their 4 9 9 integration form completion process using remote entry for applicants. We're also exceeding our year-to-date targets for both actives and historical records in The Work Number database and expect to end the year over our full year targets. Verification Services growth is -- was in excess of 20% and continues to be driven by adding records to The Work Number database and strong growth in key market verticals including auto, mortgage, consumer finance, government.
Workforce Solutions has an outstanding year in 2015 by almost any measure, driving very healthy double-digit revenue growth across multiple product offerings. And for the full year, we expect revenue growth to be in the upper teens and operating margins to settle in the upper 30s.
Against the backdrop of the changing operating environment, PSOL is consistently delivering growth in the upper end of the multiyear target range of 4% to 6%. We continue to make good progress in key metrics for our direct-to-consumer product offerings. In indirect, we have a broad and diverse set of opportunity in the pipeline, much of which is outside of the banking sector. We expect indirect to make meaningful contributions to weather growth again in 2016, and we continue to generate good growth in our International segments. As you know, that includes Canada and the U.K. Revenue growth for our direct-to-consumer activities in the U.S. was largely driven by higher average revenue for per subscriber in the quarter. For the full year, we expect Personal Solutions organic revenue growth to be within their long-term range of 4% to 6% with all the operating margins in the upper 20s. 
Let me transition back just for a second a few highlights that we talked about in the past at the corporate level level and NPI and EGI that continue to make very important contributions to our long-term growth model, provide strong discipline around the allocation of both financial capital resources enable us to execute with position. Year-to-date, our new product pipeline is expected to deliver 3-year revenue as 50% greater than the 2014 pipeline. As I mentioned earlier in my comments, that is probably the strongest I've seen since I've been here 10 years, and that bodes well obviously for 2016 and beyond. All our enterprise growth initiatives leverage our operating and project management disciplines. These disciplines ensure that we'll develop effective plans through execution and then deliver on the goals we set for ourselves. Our current view for our 2015 portfolio of EGI projects suggests that we'll exceed our full year target by almost 20%. And much like NPI, EGI is becoming a big part of our DNA in every geography and vertical we operate. Our insight strategy to global strategy is heavily dependent upon having contemporary IT platforms that can be implemented globally. In the past, you've heard us talk about the interconnect platform that was first developed in the U.S. and is now used in Canada, U.K. and Latin America. We're now in the process of taking a fraud platforming exchange that was originally deployed in U.K. and successful -- successfully deployed in Canada a few years ago and expanding around the U.S. and across Latin America. This solution provides advanced analytics and workflow as well as a known exchange focused primarily on account opening process. The skills and project management expertise our global operations COE is widely regarded and respected internally and by our customers. This organization was heavily involved in up the U.K. government opportunity for TDX, ensuring that we successfully meet all of our contractual obligation while positioning us to deliver performance, above the portfolio thresholds and collection effectiveness. More recently, we have conducted a number of customer journeys we work directly with customers on the end-to-end process with the objective of improving both the cost effectiveness of our interactions and importantly, their overall experience with us.
I'm sure you're all interested in an update on our offer to acquire the Veda Group in Australia. I'll share a few thoughts with you there. We believe this opportunity is  a nice strategic fit for Equifax, expands our geographic footprint in the core segment we know very well. Veda is a strong market -- has a strong market position, great products and data assets. They're very profitable, and they give us a strong management team in Asia. We believe Equifax' strength in advanced analytics, enterprise growth initiative, New Product Innovation and others can act to make Veda even stronger. We're currently  in the early process for Veda. And at this point, our agreements with Veda include a purchase price of AUD 2.08 to AUD 2.5 [ph]. They're not binding. As you can appreciate the transaction this time, we'll take considerable time to negotiate and finalize. We plan to conduct our usual thorough and disciplined due diligence. Simultaneously, we will negotiate the terms and conditions of the purchase agreement. Subject to successful completion of these steps, we would anticipate signing a binding agreement later this year. The final transaction is subject to the approval of the respected boards of directors, regulatory approval in Australia as well as Veda shareholders' approval. If the transaction ultimately goes forward, we anticipate completion sometime between late February and early April of 2016. At this point, I'm very confident in our ability to effectively integrate Veda should we have the opportunity to do so. 
2015 is turning out to be the strongest performance in my time with the company. As many of you know, we started the journey of transforming Equifax into a global leader in Information Solutions back in 2005. I believe we can say we have successfully transformed the culture invest our capital to support that vision, strengthen our talent base while continuously our commitments to our shareholders, customers, employees and consumers. I remain optimistic about the opportunities we have for growth in 2016 and beyond.
And with that, let me turn it over to John. John?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rick, and good morning, everyone. As before, I will generally be referring to financial results from continuing operations represented in a GAAP basis. During the quarter, we reported income of $12 million from settlement of certain escrow amounts
componenttext:
Thanks, Rick, and good morning, everyone. As before, I will generally be referring to financial results from continuing operations represented in a GAAP basis. During the quarter, we reported income of $12 million from settlement of certain escrow amounts related to an acquisition outside of the measurement period. We also recorded an expense of $8 million related to the settlement of certain specific legal claims. Consistent with our past practice for treating unusual or infrequent items, we've excluded these items from our adjusted EPS in order to provide investors with a more consistent period-to-period operating comparison. The after-tax effect of these 2 unusual items was positive $0.05 a share.
Now let me turn to the business units financial performance for the quarter. U.S. Information Solutions revenue was $312 million, up 12% when compared to the third quarter of 2014, another very strong quarter for USIS. Online Information Solutions revenue was $233 million, up 13% when compared to the year-ago period. Mortgage Solutions revenue was $32 million, up 12% compared to Q3 2014. Total mortgage-related revenue in USIS was up 20% in the quarter, and mortgage-related revenue for the total company was up 24%. This compares favorably to the Mortgage Bankers Application Index, which was up 17% in the second quarter. We currently expect total mortgage originations in the fourth quarter to be down year-over-year. For 2016, our current outlook is for mortgage originations to be about flat when compared to the full year of 2015.
On to Financial Marketing Services where revenue was $47 million, up 6% when compared to the year-ago quarter. The adjusted operating margin for U.S. Information Solutions was 41.9%, up from 40.3% in the third quarter of 2014. Internationals revenue was $149 million, flat on a reported basis but up 14% on a local currency basis. By region, Europe revenue was $64 million, up 5% in U.S. dollars but up 16% in local currency. Latin America's revenue was $52 million, up 5% in U.S. dollars and up 20% in local currency. Canada revenue was $33 million, down 13% in U.S. dollars but up 5% in local currency. For the third quarter, International's operating margin was about 20%, which is flat when compared to the second quarter of 2015. As we mentioned last quarter, we expect International operating margins to remain at about 20% throughout 2015. We expect margins to increase throughout 2016, reflecting continued strong local currency revenue growth including TDX the U.K. government contract begins to contribute as well as the benefits of regionalization and other contracts. Workforce Solutions revenue was $139 million for the quarter, up 13% when compared to the third quarter of 2014. Growth for Workforce Solutions at 13% was very strong and continue to be above our long-term model of 7% to 10%. This reflects continued very strong growth in Verification Services, up 22% year-to-year. The solid growth also reflects the following: Employer Services revenue, principally from unemployment claims, compensation claims, work opportunity tax credit and other related Employer Services declined slightly year-to-year. This reflects the continued very low levels of years unemployment as well as the timing of several authorizations in 1Q '15. Our Workforce Analytics solution for ACA compliance, which is part of our Employer Services business, continues to perform well ahead of our expectations, as Rick mentioned earlier, and now has 700-plus clients in various stages of boarding preparing for 2016 ACA reporting. However, as this is a subscription-based service in which the boarding services are offered as part of the service, all of the revenue associated with boarding and subscription service fees prior to customer production go-live is deferred and amortized over the remaining life of the agreement. As such, this brings tremendous growth in customers of activity in the second half of 15. Revenue realization will not begin until very late in 2015 and principally, 2016. Long term, we believe the subscription-based model will be greatly beneficial both in terms of customer retention and revenue profitability. It's also additive to our expectations that Workforce Solutions will continue to grow faster than our long-term 7% to 10% model. In the remainder of 2015, it will put pressure on Employer Services growth rates. In 3Q overall, Employer Services activity was more heavily skewed to ACA compliance, and that revenue was deferred and we indicated, deferred until very late 2015 and predominantly 2016. The Workforce Solutions operating margin was 35.9%, up almost 350 basis points from 3Q '14. Workforce Solutions continues to make great progress toward achieving margins consistently near 40%. Personal Solutions revenue was $67 million, up 5% on a reported basis and up 6% on a local currency basis. For the third quarter, operating margin was 26.9%, consistent with our long-term expectation for operating margins to be in the upper 20s. The year-over-year decline in operating margins is primarily driven by marketing spend at levels more consistent with our long-term expectations. In the third quarter, general corporate expense at $47 million was slightly over the guidance we gave last quarter. For the fourth quarter, we expect general corporate expense to be up slightly from the $47 million in 3Q '15. The adjusted operating margin at 27.2% was up from 26.4% in 2014 and in line with our expectations for the quarter. Our GAAP effective tax rate for the third quarter was 30.8%. This was benefited by 1.8 percentage points by the very low tax rate on the income from the settlement of the escrow we discussed earlier. Both the income from the settlement of the escrow and the related tax expense was excluded from our adjusted EPS. Excluding this 1.8 percentage point benefit, our 3Q effective tax rate was slightly higher than our effective tax rate of 32.5% in 3Q '14 and approximately consistent with the guidance we gave for the third quarter. It was also consistent with historical pattern of our third quarter effective tax rate being below the effective tax rate for the year.
Our current expectation for the effective tax rate for the full year is to be slightly less than 34%. Operating cash flow was very strong in the quarter at $247 million. With pending M&A activity, we reduced our level of stock repurchases in the quarter. Capital expenditures for the quarter were $38 million and year-to-date were $94 million. For the full year, we expect capital spending to be approximately $120 million to $125 million. This is above the approximately $100 million we discussed at the beginning of 2015. To support our continued acceleration and enterprise growth and new product innovation initiatives, we've accelerated our investments in global analytics, decisioning, broaden and change platforms and supporting network and data center infrastructure as well as internal systems. We are confident these investments will support both revenue growth and margin enhancement. At this level of investment, our capital spending continues to be at a modest 5% of revenue.
Earlier, Rick gave you an update on our proposal to acquire the Veda Group. This would be Equifax' largest acquisition in its history. And given the size of the acquisition and the upfront cost associated with the transaction and its integration, we will be excluding all acquisition-specific transaction and due diligence expense as well as integration expenses incurred in the first 12 months following the closure of the acquisition from our adjusted EPS.
Now let me turn it back to Rick.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. For the fourth quarter, we expect organic revenue to be between $655 million and $665 million, reflecting constant currency organic revenue growth of 7% to 9% and partially offset by 2% of FX headwind. This is consistent with our comments in
componenttext:
Thanks, John. For the fourth quarter, we expect organic revenue to be between $655 million and $665 million, reflecting constant currency organic revenue growth of 7% to 9% and partially offset by 2% of FX headwind. This is consistent with our comments in July that the fourth quarter organic growth would be at the high-end of our long-term range, which we talked about being 6% to 8% growth. Adjusted EPS is expected to be from $1.10 and $1.12, which is up 8% -- 8% to 10% for the quarter. Excluding $0.02 per share negative impact from FX, this reflects constant currency organic EPS growth of 10% to 12% for the quarter. Our year-to-date performance results -- our strong year-to-date performance results in an increase of our full year guidance. We can model that outlook for the fourth quarter 2015 represents an outstanding year for our shareholders, our customers, employees and consumers. And for the full year, we expect 2015 revenue to be somewhere between $2.652 billion and $2.662 billion consistent with our guidance in July and up nicely from our guidance of $2.55 billion to $2.6 billion at the beginning of the year and reflects constant currency organic revenue growth of a healthy 12% for 2015. The strong revenue growth is partially offset by 3% negative impact from FX. As before, this is only organic revenue growth, and we'll talk more about next year getting back into the M&A game. As we expect, the operating margin to be somewhere in the range of 27% to 27.5% for the full year, which is up 80 basis points over 2014. 2015 adjusted EPS is now expected to be in the range of $4.46 to $4.48 per share, up from the $4.38 to $4.42 per share we guided in July and up significantly from the $4.20 to $4.30 per share guidance we gave at the beginning of the year. That growth reflects -- that reflects a 15% growth in EPS for the year. On a constant currency basis excluding $0.11 per share of negative impact from FX, at current rates, this reflects a very strong 17% to 18% growth for the year compared to 11% growth in 2014.
Now it's early but I thought I'd give you some color on how we're thinking about 2016. And as we always do, we'll come back to give you a lot more clarity and depth on the February earnings call. As we share a look at 2016, we fully expect to be towards the upper end of our organic growth target range, which is 6% to 8% with additional growth coming from successful completion of our current M&A activities communicated -- committed to you add over time 1, 2 points of growth coming from inorganic growth, if you exclude Veda because of the size of that, our pipeline is strong, and we clearly see contributing to our organic growth of 6% to 8% and incremental 1 to 2 points coming from M&A. Veda will be incremental to that 1, 2 points. We also expect operating margins in 2016 when we exclude the impact of acquisitions to expand nicely, given the higher growth expectations we have, and this is against the backdrop of an outstanding organic growth rate in 2015. So -- and we also expect, as John said, mortgage to be relatively flat in 2016. So in summary, I think you'll agree 2015 is shaping up to be another outstanding year in 2016. Where we sit today, we're expecting another outstanding year in 2016. So operator, with that, we'd like to open up to any questions our audience may have.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll go first to David Togut from Evercore ISI.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll go first to David Togut from Evercore ISI.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015

componenttext: Rick, if I've heard you correctly, you've made a pretty compelling case for higher growth than you've laid out in your midterm targets. I mean, for example, NPI record pipeline gaining a lot of traction with EGI, Workforce Solutions performing above plan. Great traction internationally reporting products from the U.S., turned around the PSOL business, and it looks like you're on the verge of what looks to be a very accretive acquisition of Veda, at least by our calculations. So am I hearing you correctly? And if so, how do you think about sort of the mid- to long-term organic growth prospects of the business based on the hand of cards that you're looking at now?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll take it as a compliment to the team. The team can catch that effectively. The performance you're seeing in 2013, '14, '15 and kind of forward look to '16 as a result of the last 10 years of effort, laying a foundational culture and talent and p
componenttext: Well, I'll take it as a compliment to the team. The team can catch that effectively. The performance you're seeing in 2013, '14, '15 and kind of forward look to '16 as a result of the last 10 years of effort, laying a foundational culture and talent and processed like EGI MP&A others and now the benefactors of that the performance continues to be very, very broad-based across many verticals, many countries, many products. And I feel very good, very good as I sit here today looking out 2016 that the growth for 2016 will also be good as I mentioned. And we're assuming, David, in that 2016 early look, economies, GDP growth, economies to be relatively in line with what we're seeing this year, which is modest and this struggling economy in South America modest growth in GDP, U.K, Canada and U.S. at 2%, 2.5% range. So we're not expecting significant GDP market-based improvement. As you look longer term at the heart of your question, 17, 18, yes, I got hope eventually we see some rebounding, some help from the accounts we offer, and we should be -- further ones that are organic.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015

componenttext: Perhaps expand a little bit if you would on PSOL's growth prospects. You've sort of pivoted in the premium channel. You picked up some nice growth there, turned that business around. What do you see longer term in the premium channel for Equifax? How can you capitalize on the channel long term?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it's really now. You saw the announcements 2 weeks ago, that business over and think we held a job, especially when you compare it to the market as a whole to changes at such a rapid pace. I think you all agree the market share stable will al
componenttext: Yes, I think it's really now. You saw the announcements 2 weeks ago, that business over and think we held a job, especially when you compare it to the market as a whole to changes at such a rapid pace. I think you all agree the market share stable will also be a lot of work today that with outside consultants coming in. There will always be a place for the paid products that we offer, and we've done a number of interviews through third-party consultants to talk to consumers in a big cross section of the consumer base wants to, and we believe will buy the 3 products the products. Having said, is here to stay. He's carved out a nice piece. We're winning, as you know, in a free channel right now our USIS business but prays for his old job had the head the heavy hand working devising strategy for the Credit Karma and others in that arena. So simply said, the business is here to stay. The core business can grow in the mid-single digits with upper 20% margin. I'm convinced our indirect business has got good growth prospects for the next couple of years. And lastly, I'm convinced that our International presence will continue to grow strong.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015

componenttext: And obviously, it seems like a lot of your initiatives are working. The first question I had Rick was I think asked this many times before, is you talked about your NPI and now I guess EGI doing a lot better than last year and probably above your expectation. I guess how -- can you give us some color like how do you keep delivering this sort of impressive results? And does that 10% sort of NPI number you have need to go up now to maintain this level of excellence?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Truly, it's a -- we got a great team that believe in the culture of growth. I believe in the culture of helping our customers and consumers by building new solutions you could both yesterday. We got the great assets. We've invested the foundation things t
componenttext: Truly, it's a -- we got a great team that believe in the culture of growth. I believe in the culture of helping our customers and consumers by building new solutions you could both yesterday. We got the great assets. We've invested the foundation things that we talked about that. I go everyone people see it, everyone understands the importance of innovation. Our industry is by itself a high-growth industry. Our team wants to be part of a high-growth company. And the way for us to get there -- organically, to get there is through innovation. And NPI and EGI are such a vital part of who we are and how we think, it's here to stay. We'll continue to always take a step back and refresh our thinking, re-energize ourselves, modify new approach, expand the approach. We're now 10 years into NPI and probably 3 years into EGI, and those initiatives refresh periodically to make sure they're contemporary and thoughtful and the team is engaged. But as long as I'm here continues to drive for 10%-plus index because it's healthy.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then one follow-up on Veda. I mean, clearly, sounds like a good deal. It's a public company. I guess what I'm trying to get is, in your diligence, are there a couple of key things that you guys really need to get out or is it just making sure yo
componenttext: Okay. And then one follow-up on Veda. I mean, clearly, sounds like a good deal. It's a public company. I guess what I'm trying to get is, in your diligence, are there a couple of key things that you guys really need to get out or is it just making sure you're checking the boxes?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, there are, obviously. And by no means would I ever going to a diligence process spending any amount of money along [ph] $1.7 billion, $1.8 billion with the mindset just to check the box. We take acquisitions extremely seriously thoughtfully, and I pr
componenttext: Yes, there are, obviously. And by no means would I ever going to a diligence process spending any amount of money along [ph] $1.7 billion, $1.8 billion with the mindset just to check the box. We take acquisitions extremely seriously thoughtfully, and I prefer not to disclose the exact list of diligence items that we've highlighted. Trust me. It'll be thorough diligence. We're in the data room now. will be in the country in a week, and we have a very thoughtful exhausted list of questions to the board. And I along with the business unit leaders and COE leaders thoroughly vetted. So we have thorough diligence nowhere close to a perfunctory check box.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I first want to ask, could you maybe provide a little more insight into how, one, we should be thinking about the magnitude of the contribution from the partnership with Fannie Mae as we think about our 2016 models for next year? And two, we've heard a lo
componenttext: I first want to ask, could you maybe provide a little more insight into how, one, we should be thinking about the magnitude of the contribution from the partnership with Fannie Mae as we think about our 2016 models for next year? And two, we've heard a lot of companies looking more at trends of data generally. So maybe you could talk a bit about have you seen demands for that product evolve, and we should think about that over the medium term to contribute to growth.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: The Fannie Mae one is a great one. It's great one for consumers. It's a great for the underwriters and going to be a great one for our business unit -- business units of USIS and EWS. As I mentioned I think in my comments earlier, we expect that to ramp u
componenttext: The Fannie Mae one is a great one. It's great one for consumers. It's a great for the underwriters and going to be a great one for our business unit -- business units of USIS and EWS. As I mentioned I think in my comments earlier, we expect that to ramp up probably late second quarter, early third quarter. So what we're going to do is got to fine-tune to bring that to market for Fannie Mae, and it's got meaningful impact for the business units next year. I'm not going to give you an exact number, but it will be meaningful for us at the BU level. Two, if you think in general terms, I think 2 years ago, we started talking to you about trended data and their interest in getting historical versus snapshot look. And the first thing we did was built capabilities for batch offline and called it CMS. That ramped up nicely. We've been through a technology investment we made in USIS and recently brought that capability to go online, and that's now ramping up nicely. And I'm also very, very intrigued with the concept on trended data of bringing that we're looking at now is a technology requirement as well bring EWS. The concept of taking one of the many different attributes we have in The Work Number database, that attribute being income and showing an underwriter, a marketeer, whoever a historical look a trended look at their income intellectually excites myself and the team. So as I think about trended data, we're the next evolution that we'll invest data towards verification of income.

componenttext: Yes, I believe the comments I made -- I could check my notes here. The USIS NPI pipeline is running at a rate of 50% greater than the pipeline we had in 2014. So that revenue earn-out in USIS over the next 3 years of 15% reflect in 2014.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Rick, the 700 clients you signed for ACA platform, I know the revenue hasn't started, but can you -- any way to help us size that for 2016 as you roll in? And then second, International margins, I know you said they'll be up 2016 and they were as high as
componenttext: Rick, the 700 clients you signed for ACA platform, I know the revenue hasn't started, but can you -- any way to help us size that for 2016 as you roll in? And then second, International margins, I know you said they'll be up 2016 and they were as high as 20 -- almost 29% a few years ago. Is there anything different within International business today that will keep you from getting back to those numbers? And how many years do you think it takes to get back to it?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think color and texture around ETA the past earnings calls, one, the caveat I'll give you is we've always -- will be very meaningful for EWS. Very meaningful, and it exceeds my expectations. I mean it's so far beyond expectations we had a year ago. John
componenttext: I think color and texture around ETA the past earnings calls, one, the caveat I'll give you is we've always -- will be very meaningful for EWS. Very meaningful, and it exceeds my expectations. I mean it's so far beyond expectations we had a year ago. John mentioned, I mentioned over 700-plus accounts, strong interest level already brewing for 2016 follow the ACA series dynamics to and the level of how those increased over the years, the appeal processing, that's going to have a tail that's for many years as see look out. And secondly, and I alluded to it, getting into this ACA is going to open up about other doors and opportunity we thought about yet appeals process and so on and so forth. So I'm not going to give you a number it is meaningful and very, very, very important to us in the long term. Again, I think the rest of my comments probably the most impactful, largest meaningful we had in my 10 years here. As far as margins on International, yes, I clearly see 2015 as being the trough, if you will, on margins. That was intentional. We're integrating a big acquisition for that we're investing heavily in the U.K. business unit, U.K. government opportunity talked about. Also, as John alluded to in our comments, investing heavily in technology analytics and platforms around the International operations to fuel growth short, medium and the long term. So we clearly expect 2015 to drop margins nicely in 2016 and beyond. Will they get back to 29% [ph] ? Theres one caveat for that I think they can over time and period over time is the team is working diligently now to regionalize big pockets of cost within International, and that requires technology investment to take things from countries to regions and so on and so forth. That will be a big factor. If we are fortunate enough to close the acquisition of Veda, we clearly expect EBITDA margin basis, that's also be a nice lift to the EBITDA margins of International.

componenttext: Rick, I wanted to ask you about peer-to-peer lenders. This was a subject that came up recently when I hosted an industry research conference call with And I just want to know you look at these peer-to-peer lenders, I know they are using Equifax products today, but I want to look further out. Do you think these peer-to-peer lending systems will lead to an increase of demand of Equifax products or decrease when it comes to peer-to-peer lenders?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's a good question. We spend a lot of time thinking about that strategically and many do refer to that ecosystem as evolving as you had this peer-to-peer. I'd like to think of it as a remote lending, unsecured remote lending rather than peer-to-peer l
componenttext: That's a good question. We spend a lot of time thinking about that strategically and many do refer to that ecosystem as evolving as you had this peer-to-peer. I'd like to think of it as a remote lending, unsecured remote lending rather than peer-to-peer lending club or green sky or business credit or others. One point I think is that is a market placement that will exist. I think that the strip the marketplace for the traditional banking sector the banks participate themselves I think it's you're mistaken think it's got good momentum, good legs. As we mentioned before, they are a user of our data. Today, they use both the verification deployment and in some database many times as well as core credit scores. and we expect that to continue going forward. So right now I view that as being yet another -- if that sector can allow maybe other people to get access to credit, the normal system that's incremental to us if that's just displacement bank would underwrite today, a nonevent for us. The bigger question we're thinking about strategically is how else can we play that ecosystem? In 5, 10 years is a big robust part of the market and how do we participate in the market right now.

componenttext: Rick, I just want to know if you want to comment a little bit more on Veda. That company is doing very well. It actually looks like a mini Equifax, and you touched on it a little bit in your comments. I want to know if you can expand a little bit on this. What does it to bring to them? And what is it that they bring to you beyond on kind of the geographic diversification?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: One, notice, we have a -- Schlomo, a number of years, you know our thoughts on acquisitions, so this won't surprise the rest of you or you. We have been talking with Veda now maybe 4 year. So it's not like this thing dropped out of the sky 1 day. We said
componenttext: One, notice, we have a -- Schlomo, a number of years, you know our thoughts on acquisitions, so this won't surprise the rest of you or you. We have been talking with Veda now maybe 4 year. So it's not like this thing dropped out of the sky 1 day. We said this to be an interesting acquisition. It's been an organization that we try to get to know each other for quite some time. So philosophically, it's important to know that when we think of acquisitions and Equifax, we are driven by a view of what we can bring to that company that makes that company even better, rather than what does that company bring to us that makes Equifax better? Studies will show and consultants when you take the path of how they help you as a core business, it oftentimes fail. So with that, having said that, other geographical footprint I think what we can bring there is some of the processes and capabilities that have made Equifax successful the last 10 years in the countries we operate now, things like our LEAN process, things like the customer, things like NPI, things like EGI and price growth initiatives, our Cambrian technology platform, which is fabulous. And as you know, we've been investing for a number of years bringing that platform to countries in which they operate and link together unstructured Internet data, if you will, third-party customer data and our data and build more products we can build in the past. I think that's a great capability, so it's really deploying some of the things we know so well, Shlomo that we put here into the footprint. And I do think that over time the things will have to determine is clearly not baked into any pro forma assumptions that we have now. Over time, if we have a really good business in that part of the world, we got really good people, which they do, our ability to think about expanding to other geographies now the 2 businesses are much bigger business investments organically and inorganically, I think when you close those geographies, I really want to make those bets. Sitting here in Atlanta, Georgia, trying to think about making investments in midsized countries around Southeast Asia, and the hub is a risk take and got the good footprint in Australia and a few other countries, that's a risk we'll take as a company, and that will the evolve over the next few years.

componenttext: That's a great question. I think as we've gotten to know the company, more definitely the past 2 years, we're getting a couple. Two, I think it's opportunistic time as well. So maybe last point is we bought TDX roughly 2 years ago. We delevered TDX. we integrated TDX successfully. So the balance sheet, our human capital, preparedness is in a position to capitalize on big acquisitions. So all these things kind of came together at the right time.
